Jacob Rees-Mogg warns May she&rsquos UNDERESTIMATING Brexiteers as MPs v...                Brexit deal &lsquoDONE&rsquo - Memo reveals UK exit to be &lsquofinalised TODAY'The emails are particularly important because the Government currently relies on the support of 10 DUP MPs for its Commons majority.Earlier this week, the DUP threatened to vote against the upcoming budget if Theresa May agrees to trade barriers between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, in a move which could bring down the Government.Talks between the UK and EU remain at loggerheads over whether the backstop period, when the UK will remain aligned with the European single market, should be time-limited.The backstop will come into place if the UK and EU can&rsquot agree to a comprehensive deal on their future trade relationship.Arlene Foster said the DUP was ready for the possibility of a no-deal scenario (Image: )&ldquoShe described Barnier as being difficult and hostile in her meeting today (Image: )It is intended to stop any hard border being needed between Ireland and Northern Ireland.The plan has been condemned by some Brexiteers, who argue it would leave the UK subservient to EU rules and unable to sign its own trade deals.In a piece for the Belfast News Letter, former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, argued: &ldquoIf we let this go it will be the greatest national humiliation since Suez.&ldquoThe only way to put things back on the right track is to ditch the backstop and then to chuck Chequers.Several Cabinet Ministers are demanding any UK alignment with the customs union is clearly time-limited, to prevent the UK indefinitely abiding by EU rules.                Bank chief in urgent order to Italy to STOP questioning euro                Brexiteers could VOTE DOWN Budget 'to BLOCK &pound39bn orce bill'&ldquoIf we let this go it will be the greatest national humiliation since Suez (Image: )However, Brussels is refusing to approve a time-limit.A number of ministers including Esther McVey are believed to be &ldquoseriously considering their positions on this over the weekend and could resign in protest.Even if a deal is agreed the Government may struggle to get it through Parliament.Analysis by the Edelman public affairs consultancy concluded that Mrs May can only rely on the support of 277 of her 314 Conservative MPs, and may well need some Labour support to get her Brexit deal through Parliament.

title: Bavaria election 2018 polls Angela Merkel Germany Manfred Weber CSU
story: Speaking to Euronews, the Christian Social Union (CSU) MEP argued the result of the Bavaria regional election depended on the unresolved issue of migration in the Brussels bloc.&nbspAngela Merkel's ally claimed it was time Europe delivered a solution to the migration problem and stopped feeding populists around the bloc.&nbspMr Weber said: &ldquoWe saw all over Europe that the migration question is the dominating issue in the campaigns.&ldquoAnd we are at the moment suffering as CSU from this debate.                Merkel will be blamed for 'dramatic' Bavaria election on Sunday&ldquoI think what we have to do is give people an idea that we have a solution.&ldquoWe can solve the problem.&ldquoThat means, first of all, that Europe must deliver.&ldquoAt the European Council meeting next week I expect results on this question because otherwise, we will feed the populists if we cannot give a proper answer.Voters will take to the polls on Sunday to elect the 180 members of the 18th Landtag of Bavaria.Bavaria election: CSU Manfred Weber pleads for EU's help to win Bavaria election (Image: &bullEURONEWS)The regional elections could weaken the national government if the CSU is not successful and blame is placed on Horst Seehofer, who is Ms Merkel&rsquos Interior Minister and leader of the CSU.The CSU, which is Ms Merkel&rsquos coalition partner and Bavarian sister party to the CDU, will be contesting the vote on October 14 against the Alternative for Germany (AfD) anti-immigration party.The AfD has surged in popularity with anti-Islamic rhetoric and attacks on Chancellor Angela Merkel's migrant policy - a hot topic in Bavaria, where most of the 1.5 million asylum seekers who reached Germany in the past three years entered the country.The party&rsquos rise has decimated support for Mrs Merkel's Bavarian allies the Christian Social Union (CSU) which is set to lose the absolute majority with which it has controlled the southern state for most of the post-war period.The loss of the CSU&rsquos absolute majority in Bavaria would put yet more pressure on Mrs Merkel&rsquos crisis-torn coalition Government and could potentially lead to its downfall.A poll published by German broadcaster ARD last week showed support for the CSU had fallen to 33 percent, despite usually getting around 50 percent of the vote.The poll showed the Greens Party in second place, with 18 percent voter support.This was ahead of the Social Democrats, who were at 11 percent, with the far-right AfD slightly behind with 10 percent.As a result, this could be the CSU&rsquos worst performance since 1950, when it received 27.4 percent of the vote.

title: brexit theresa may conservative labour
story: We understand her desperation to avoid no-deal.It would be damaging for both sides, which is why German and Spanish businesses are panicking.But to challenge the DUP to like her deal or lump it, when they are openly threatening to defeat the Budget, looks reckless.Eventhey don’t, she still needs their votes to govern post-Brexit.And can the Prime Minister really trust the supposedly sensible wing of the Labour Party to make up the numbers on the final deal The worst of it, though, is agreeing to stay in the EU’s Customs Union “temporarily” but with no firm exit date.It is simply dishonest to spend two years talking up our golden opportunities to embrace global free trade and new industriesyou know that, in ­reality, we could be trapped forever in a deal that snuffs them out.We MUST be out of the Customs Union by the next election.Our future and the Government’s survival depend on it.NOTHING is more toxic to a party’s fortunes than betraying promises to voters.Brown did it. Clegg too. Theresa May doesn’t seem to have learned the lesson.Announcing that “austerity is over” looks hasty. Corbyn will throw it back at her whenever ANY spending is cut.The same goes for the PM’s manesto pledges to cut tax on “businesses and working families”.Chancellor Philip Hammond plainly intends the opposite to fund her NHS splurge.The Tories claim “we will always be a party of low tax”. How, with the overall burden already at a -year high FOR all the gloom, it could be worse. We could be victims of John McDonnell’s socialist fantasy, as the children dying of hunger in Venezuela are.Inflation there has hit ten million per cent. Yes, you read that right.The squalor and misery are almost unimaginable. Yet just four years ago the Shadow Chancellor rejoiced that the once-rich South American country was now experiencing “socialism in action”.The warning signs of collapse were already there. Essentials were running out. Renationalisations, price controls, the trampling on the rule of law and lack of private investment saw to that.McDonnell ignored it all. And he won’t care one bitwe suffer such horrors too. His lelong dream is to unleash the same lunatic experiment here.Voters, and Labour’s own more moderate MPs, must never give him that chance.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: its simply sickening to spend 4bn abroad on dubious foreign aid projects
story: But it is simply sickening to spend £billion abroad upgrading road and rail schemes and urban infrastructure.Look at the appalling state of OUR roads, needing a £billion fix of their own. Look at our shambolic rail system and its creaking, crumbling infrastructure overseen by state-run Network Rail.Look at our public finances, our deficit, our gargantuan debt. Look at the local councils facing bankruptcy.Listen to the Government, now facing a headache over Universal Credit, insisting every penny must be made to count.We are entitled to expect decent public services infor our taxes. What justication can there be for hiving off billions from them to improve transport systems in Pakistan Or in India, which has billions for a fleet of new warships and a space programme but needs the British public’s generosity to mend its roads It is insane. The consequence of an idiotic law which compels us to donate billions every year no matter how dire our finances or how spurious the cause.The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But not for foolish virtue-signalling on the world stage.It is an abuse of public funds and a cast-iron election loser.THERESA May must find the cash to help those losing out in the sht to Universal Credit.The new scheme DOES work well for many. It is far simpler and, crucially, incentivises work. But cuts by former Chancellor George Osborne are now biting too hard. Some claimants face a severe blow to their income.If the PM is genuinely “listening to concerns”, as she says, then good.Voters generally back less generous benefit payments. Especially compared with the absurd levels under the last Labour Government, which fostered idleness and trapped huge numbers permanently on the dole. But Brits are famously keen on fair play too.They won’t support families being stripped of money through no fault of their own.KIDS don’t need a smartphone in class. It can only wreck their concentration and harm their education.How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat Other countries have done already.But generations of pupils survived without them. Below the bed is the bathroom, complete with toilet and shower.A Spotahome spokesperson said: Spotahome is an online residential rentals  that aims to demonstrate each property in a realistic manner through photos, detailed videos and floor plans.Our job is to very the property’s existence, features and location to facilitate rentals without in-person viewings.As a marketplace, it is the landlord’s responsibility to ensure they meet all legal requirements.Clearly this listing didn’t meet requirements as it only has a -ring hob and minimum standards require a -ring hob with oven and grill, and a cooker hood.We have taken the feedback from Twitter users on board, and have unpublished the property.In regards to the price, landlords set their own pricing, terms and conditions and the contract is signed directly between the tenant and the landlord.

title: mh370 news cambodian jungle malaysia airlines logo
story: The online hunt for the jet intensied after what appeared to be wreckage was found on Google Maps in the jungle by Brit Ian Wilson.A second “crash site” ten miles away was then seen on satellite images by fellow part-time plane-hunter Daniel Boyer.And he now says he can make out the aircraft’s cockpit and tail in the grainy pics.The photos show several white objects lying on the forest floor north-west of Cambodia’s capital Phnom Penh.Boyer told the Daily Star one piece measures .ft – close to the ft in of a Boeing  cockpit, leaving him “convinced” this was the front of the plane.And he insisted he can see the red outline of Malaysia Airlines’ logo on another piece, which he said must be the tail.The piece apparently measures .ft – whereas a tail piece normally measures ft.Mr Boyer told the website: “I couldn’t believe it when I made the sighting.“First the cockpit can be seen, and now this.“The debris definitely needs to be investigated.”The first images of the jet, which vanished on March , , were found after video producer Ian Wilson spent hours searching online.Images from Google Maps showed the outline of a large plane in a remote part of southern Cambodia  – which could simply be an aircraft flying directly below the satellite which photographed it.But Google Earth’sdate and imagery date for the picture have been listed as dferent years in recent weeks, reports The Daily Star.This has led to speculation the supposed wreckage has been snapped several times in the past by the tech giant’s satellites - ruling out the theory that Wilsons picture shows a plane in flight.While the current imagery date is listed as March , last week it was reportedly published as December .It has also been claimed the outline of the plane was spotted in May, , using Google Maps – just two months after the jet vanished.Wilson believes this adds further credence to his theory and says he plans to visit the site with his brother – in a bid to capture the £million finder’s fee.He told the Star: “After much discussion last night, we’re just organising final vaccinations and the hiring of guides.”But aviation expert Yijun Yu puts the imagery date mystery down to either a system glitch or that Google hasn’t updated its pictures for the spot.Flight  disappeared on March , , en route from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing with  people on board.Just  minutes into the flight, MH lost contact with Malaysia Airlines.The plane was never found despite a search that cost millions and lasted for years.Various theories - some more viable than others - emerged to explain what happened to the plane.Other than the Cambodian jungle theory, these include the suicidal pilot deliberately crashing into the sea, the aircraft being shot down by North Korea and a conspiracy to bring down the Malaysian government.

title: uk weather storm callum mum baby avoid crushed tree
story: Ellie Jaeger-Fozard and -month-old Richard were sat in the vehicle in Edgerton, Yorks, when the near miss happened.They were waiting for dad James to finish up at work as the branch was torn off in the strong winds.Ellie, , of Newsome, said her heart was in her mouth as the branch fell across the road with a sickening thud onto the car bonnet and windscreen.She said: I couldnt believe it. If I had parked just a few inches further up the road it could have been very dferent.Richard was in the passenger seat and playing with the steering wheel as he waited for his daddy to arrive when the tree crashed down.Fortunately I managed to get him out and phoned the police. The bonnet was dented and the windscreen was hit by the falling tree too.Grandad Neil Harling was soon on the scene after hearing about what had happened to his daughter.He said: Im just very glad that everyone is OK and no-one has been hurt. It doesnt bear thinking about what might have been.James added: I think we will all be having a stf drink tonight. Im just so relieved everyone is OK.Police arrived immediately and set about taping off the scene and waited for a tree surgeon to arrive and begin removing it.Kirklees councillor Gemma Wilson said: I live in Edgerton and Ive been quite nervous about the trees outside my home, it has been very blustery indeed.Im really glad that mum and baby are OK, it must have been a terrible shock for something like that to happen. Lets hope the winds start to calm down soon.As the storm grips the UK one part of south Wales, the Brecon Beacons village of Libanus, recorded mm of rain in just  hours - way above the monthly total for the region of mm.A number of weather warnings are in place until late this evening - with an amber warning for rain for south Wales where flooding is likely.Met Office meteorologist Helen Roberts said: There will be more wet and windy weather for similar parts of the country - predominantly western areas - which could cause more flooding.The east and south east of England will see the best of the drier and brighter weather, where it will be even warmer than yesterday and could reach C - way above average for the time of the year.Temperatures are up for this time of year, with highs of C possible in the south east today.Tomorrow it is expected to fall back to closer to average, with temperatures of around -C predicted.The rain is set to continue through central and southern parts of the country this evening, before it starts to clear tomorrow.

title: us remote controlled terminator tanks invisibility cloaking
story: But these so-called terminator tanks could be much closer to reality than you may think and the United States is leading the charge.The military wants to test its Robotic Combat Vehicle demonstrator ready by as early as , news.au reports.These war machines would be driven remotely by soldiers sitting safely in US bases in the same way unmanned drones are.They will also be invisible to the enemy and coated in armour which reacts to oncoming fire.Here, we look at the state-of-the-art tech which could shape the face of modern warfare forever...At the annual Association of the US Armymeeting in Washington DC this week, companies large and small from around the United States brought their latest and greatest tech to showcase.One exciting contender was BAE Systems’ CV MkIV tank-like vehicle — a self-driving and self-fighting combat vehicle. And a potentially “invisible” one at that.It has a “man-optional” combat mode and potentially allows the military to take humans out of the battle physically by operating the vehicle remotely.The tank features advanced Active Protection System and crew protection from heavy weaponry including IEDs, antitank mines and chemical, biological, radiological and nuclearattacks.BAE’s ADAPTIV program provides camouflage that renders the vehicle essentially “invisible” to enemy forces using “active multi-spectral cloaking”.The cloaking can make the vehicle blend into the background so it seems to vanish. It can even mimic other objects making the tank look like rocks or a car in the eyes of the enemyneed be.The Defensive Aid Suite enables the armoured vehicle to classy targets, give warnings about threats and best manoeuvre guidance to others in the battle space. To prevent the vehicle from getting hit, it can also deploy countermeasures by itself.Human crews can operate from inside the vehicle, but it can also be controlled remotely — from anywhere in the world.The CV tends to involve a two-man turret armed with Bushmaster cannons. This remote-controlled solution allows powerful weapons to be unleashed on the battlefield but reduces the risk to soldiers by taking them out of the turret.The vehicle’s weaponry can be tailored to requirements and there’s quite a range of options — including weapons that can hit enemy aircraft and tanks.Its Fire Control System can already autonomously set the type of ammunition most suitable to defeat these threats, as well as automatically calculating the angles for maximum accuracy. By itself, the vehicle can also choose whether the best approach will be airburst, impact or delayed detonation.In the long term, combat vehicles may conduct missions entirely on their own however it is more likely there will always be humans in the loop.Soldiers could, for example, operate the unmanned CV MkIV combat vehicle while on-board another vehicle to amply the force.Or dismounted soldiers could control the unmanned vehicles, using them to perform reconnaissance in advance of troops.Patrols, whether dismounted or in vehicles, could pilot the smart combat vehicles to travel in front of them so that in the event of an IED the unmanned vehicle would be hit instead of soldiers.From inside a base, soldiers could also send the vehicles out on patrols.And of course, battalions of robotic combat vehicles could eventually be deployed in battles.A version of this story appeared on news.au

title: democratic football lads alliance march turns violent as far right supporters clash with cops
story: Dozens of DFLA protesters were seen fighting with police officers, with one threatening a cop and screaming “I’ll kill you”, according to reports.The clash – which resulted in at least one arrest – came despite the alliance telling its supporters to remain “respectful and decent” during today’s demonstration.Several hostile-looking men had to be held back from joining in the fighting by their friends, said the Press Association.The Anti-Fascist Network said that its counter demonstration to show opposition to the event resulted in the DFLA being “sandwiched” by their black-clad supporters and police following the alliances march.On Facebook, DFLA march organisers explained they were protesting against ing jihadists, thousands of AWOL migrants, rape gangs and groomers, and veterans treated like traitors.Prior to todays event, they had urged people to “take to the streets to highlight the cost of austerity, the uncontrolled kne crime, the plight of victims of rape and abuse and PTSDthat our unaccountable government is responsible for.“We need to be aware that the left are going to try and goad you, to provoke you to violence. Remember,you respond you may as well hand them a child to be abused, so stand strong, stand proud, do not give into them.“We will have the attention of the media with us, this is our chance to influence the nation, to get Government to sit up and take note. We are the kingmakers.“This will be the day we saved our country from Westmonster.”Hundreds of DFLA supporters were walking from Park Lane to Whitehall before some of them started to push through their police escorts, reported the PA.Peter Mantell, , attending the demonstration from Crayford, told the PA: I detest some of the people Im walking with. A lot of them hate people because of the colour of their skin.Im a lefty. But I believe we should have a voice against the people who want to hurt everyone and cause harm.He also admitted that he was a supporter of former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson.Many demonstrators could be heard chanting whose streets  Our streets  as they marched down Pall Mall.Scores of police on horseback and wearing riot gear tried to control the swelling groups with police vans trying to block them in, as some yelled at them for alleged inaction against paedos and grooming gangs, reported MailOnline.One person watching the clashes described it on Twitter as an “absolute scruffy shambles. Their [DFLA] pathetic march blocked by a much larger anti-fascist turnout”.Another man tweeted about seeing “intense scenes at Trafalgar Square. As a bystander, without any kind of political stand, I’ve just been verbally abused by a man with a shaved head, brandishing a St George’s cross flag and dragging a small child round.”Prior to the event, the politan police said it had imposed conditions upon marches and rallies being planned by the DFLA, and also upon the anti-fascist counter demonstration.This stipulated that protesters must start their march at Park Lane, and continue along Piccadilly, St Jamess Street, Pall Mall, Trafalgar Square and ending at Whitehall.The force asked attendees to conduct themselves peacefully, whatever your view... failure to adhere to these conditions may lead to arrest and prosecution.” said that thousands of people attended the event.

title: princess eugenie stuns in official royal wedding photos as she poses next to smiling queen
story: The  Duchess of York, , stood smiling next to her old foe Prince Philip for the happy family snap.Eugenie, , her husband Jack Brooksbank, ,   and other senior members of The Firm, including The Queen, joined the line-up.Last night royal watchers said the image appeared to be a signicant step to ending a feud that has raged for almost three decades since Fergie separated from Prince Andrew.Prince Philip, , has never forgiven his former daughter-in-law for the toe-sucking pictures of her and Texan financial adviser John Bryan in .They were taken months after she and Andrew announced they were splitting.The group photograph was released last night by Buckingham Palace.It was taken in the White Drawing Room of Windsor Castle following  Friday’s wedding.Royal author and commentator Phil Dampier said: “It is highly signicant — and could be a step to ending the feud.“It shows Sarah Ferguson right at the centre of the Royal Family once again and will only fuel rumours that she and Prince Andrew might one day remarry.“Most signicantly,  she is standing right next to Prince Philip, who hasn’t spoken to her in more than  years.“He once called her ‘odd’ and ‘pointless’ and would not be in the same room as her. In recent years, Sarah has been invited to stay with the Queen  at Balmoral.Each time, she  has had to leave the day before Prince Philip arrives.“He blamed her for bringing shame on the Royal Family and could not understand why Andrew let her move back in with him at Royal Lodge, his home at Windsor, when they had been orced for so many years.“I understand that Prince Philip and Fergie did have a brief conversation at the reception in Windsor Castle after  the wedding.“Philip would not have wanted to cause bad feeling at the wedding and upset his granddaughter Eugenie.“But maybe, at , he has decided that le is too short to continue bearing Fergie ill will.“Fergie will be relieved that she is no longer a figure of ridicule and has been shown compassion and respect by Philip in posing up with her.”Prince Andrew poked fun at groom Jack  during his  wedding speech, cheekily declaring that he had MI spooks check out his new son-in-law.The Duke of York, ,  also left guests in stitches when he took aim at ex-we Fergie’s punctuality.On its front page  yesterday, The Sun  told how the Duchess was six minutes late for the wedding in St George’s Chapel at Windsor Castle.Andrew playfully told guests while looking at Fergie: “It’s great having the whole family together — evensome of us nearly didn’t make it.”Fergie was snap-happy with her camera, keen to document every last detail of Eugenie’s special day.She and Andrew  — parents to Eugenie and Princess Beatrice,  —  orced in . But they have remained good friends and were both closely involved with planning the wedding.The official photo shows groom Jack’s brother and best man Tom, and their parents,  Nicola and George.Princess Beatrice stands behind the Queen and Prince Philip.Children on the front row include the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s eldest children Prince George, five, and Princess Charlotte, three Robbie Williams’ daughter Teddy, six and Zara and Mike Tindall’s daughter Mia, four.Also pictured are Maud, the five-year-old daughter of Lord and Lady Frederick Windsor page boy Louis de Givenchy, six and the daughters of Peter and Autumn Phillips, six-year-old Isla  and Savannah, seven.

title: panic rooms new york mansions ms 13 gang
story: Eastern parts of Long Island – including The Hamptons – have long attracted the rich and famous, and are filled with swanky restaurants and plush homes.But many homeowners are now so terried by rising crime that they are turning their homes into fortresses equipped with bulletproof glass, weaponry and panic rooms.John Catsimatidis who has a holiday home in East Quogue, said: “I sleep with a gun underneath my pillow. A Walther PPK S, the same one James Bond carried.“[My we] Margo prefers a shotgun.“Although, once, she thought she heard something, got the shotgun out and shot through the door.”The billionaire and his family, like others in the Hamptons, are shaken up over concerns that the vicious Salvadorian gang MS- is too close for comfort.In April, members of the gang massacred four young men behind a football pitch on the island.And in , a man with MS- connections broke into a Southampton home and sexually assaulted a woman.Last year, Southampton Town Police Chief Steven Skrynecki publicly expressed concern that the gang might spread further east.When he deployed police equipped with anti-terrorism gear, including automatic weapons, along the perimeters of summer  charity galas, locals took note.One Southampton homeowner, who asked to remain anonymous, recently outfitted her pad with bulletproof glass and hidden cameras throughout.She said: “[MS- is] in Suffolk County. What’s an hour car ride  They are near.”She’s not alone in her concern.Gary Blum is president of Armored Entry, a company that installs bullet-proof, super-secure windows and doors.He said: “The home-security business is very event- and news-driven.“We get business when there is a tremendous amount of fear being generated.”Blum’s products aren’t cheap, starting at £, for a single window “that you can beat with a sledgehammer without making a dent”.But the high price might actually be a selling point.Panic room installer Chris Cosban said: “The big thing [with homeowners] in the Hamptons is thatsomebody has it, they [all] want it.”His company, Covert Interiors, charges between £, and £, for a standard space.High-tech add-ons, such as fingerprint recognition, cost extra.But that’s nothing compared to the security measures that Al Corbi, president of SAFE , an architecture-focused security firm, has designed for customers.He said of one project: “I finished a system for million .“That sounds like a lot but there is nothing I know of, human or manmade, that could possibly harm this family for three generations, including global nuclear holocaust, a pandemic or a second Ice Age.”He added: “It’s like a Ritz-Carlton underground.” A version of this story originally appeared on New York Post.

title: we dont owe musical genius to the eu
story: Fine, highfalutin words, Bono.But try telling them to the ­millions of young people who are unemployed in Italy, Spain and Greece, the economies of those proud countries dragged down by the dead weight of the euro. And try out the windbag oratory on the .million decent British democrats who voted to leave the European Union, and who have been told ever since that they are racist, ignorant ­bigots who should never be allowed near a polling booth.I like Bono. In person, he is a decent, thoughtful man. His band are not bad. But why do the former rebels of rock music always tug their forelocks to the European Union  Why does everyone in leather trousers act like the EU is an unalloyed good thing  Why does rock music have a blind spot when it comes to Brussels How can Bono, right, possibly mistake Jean-Claude Juncker for Joe Strummer   The EU is the ESTABLISHMENT, man! And the EU is the ­establishment at its most ­unaccountable, undemocratic, incompetent and corrupt.The EU is not a beautul thing, Bono. It is a crumbling ­expansionist empire, rotten to the core, merciless in its opposition to democracy.The EU is a gravy train, Bono, a trough for puffed-up political piggies, a sclerotic body of ­privileged old white men in suits with MEPs who do not have to provide receipts for their £,-a-month expenses. The EU really stinks, Bono.And the music that you and I grew up with — the music we loved, the music U and I were inspired by, the music we placed at the centre of our worlds — was meant to be against this kind of thing. Bono bent the knee to the bullies of Brussels in the same week that Bob Geldof sent a ­letter to Theresa May warning her that Brexit will be the day the music dies.“Imagine Britain without its music,” thundered Geldof’s letter, co-signed by musicians including Sting, Ed Sheeran, Jarvis Cocker and Damon Albarn. “If it’s hard for us, then it’s impossible for the rest of the world. Britain does rule the waves. The airwaves. But Brexit threatens, as it does so much , this vast voice.”But it is simply not true that our country owes its musical genius to the European Union. The golden years of British music were before we joined the EU — when it was still being touted to us as a common market — back in .The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, The Who, The Kinks, Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin all somehow managed to make great music without Brussels. Now Geldof and his co-signatories seriously suggest that British music can’t survive outside the European Union.No doubt the Brexit-loathing Boomtown Rat believes this rubbish but everyone  who signed his Whinge Aid letter should have paused to think before signing. Because by claiming that Brexit will kill British music, Ed Sheeran, Sting and the rest just make themselves look like laughably out-of-touch luvvies. Not a good look for the wild boys of rock ’n’ roll.Geldof is right about one thing — British music has been brilliant for  years because our little country embraced the world.But John Lennon, Jimmy Page, Joe Strummer, Mick Jones, Ray Davies, Robert Plant, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and Pete Townshend opened their ears and their hearts to the sounds coming out of America.The glorious music that smashed down the walls between white music and black music was born in Chicago and Nashville and Detroit and Memphis.  Its roots were in the backwoods of the Deep South and the ­Mississippi Delta, and reached all the way back to Africa. Belgium never came into it, Bob.The Rolling Stones never needed a grant from the EU. They just needed one glimpse of Buddy Holly, one listen to Muddy Waters, one nod from Elvis Presley. British bands changed the world and they sure as hell did it without the help of the European Union. Sorry, Bob. Sorry, Bono. But no British musician in history was ever inspired by the mysterious rhythms coming out of Brussels.PETER JACKSON’S new film, They Shall Not Grow Old, shows painstakingly coloured images from World War One for the very first time.Because we have only experienced World War One in black and white footage and photos, there has always felt like a huge distance between our time and the unimaginable horrors of the trenches.Lord Of The Rings director Jackson has bridged that gap and the results, above, take your breath away. He says: “The war was a colour war. You’re seeing it as they saw it. And they saw it in colour.”World War One never felt closer. And the humour, humanity and courage of the men who fought it has never been more heartbreaking.BEST wishes for the future to Trevor Engelson and his bride Tracey Kurland, who were married in a low-key ceremony in Calornia last weekend.Andyou don’t recognise the names, that is because Mr Engelson has chosen to keep a discreet silence on the subject of his two-year marriage to Meghan Markle.And in an age where every broken relationship is ­dissected on social media, isn’t it refreshing to see a man who can keep a dignied silence “WE lost the match but won the battle,” claimed Conor McGregor after his beating in last weekend’s UFC .  What planet was that victory on then, Conor To the casual fan it looked like McGregor  followed up months of denigrating Khabib Nurmagomedov with a feeble performance in the octagon and a lack of grace in defeat.True, Khabib spoilt his victory by jumping into the crowd to continue the punch-up with McGregor’s corner.  But for the le of me I can’t see how Conor McGregor can claim anything other than unconditional surrender. Neither man brought credit to MMA.There is only one reason why mainstream sports fans have been paying interest to Mixed Martial Arts in recent years and that is Conor McGregor. But after the squalid scenes around Conor v Khabib, many of us will be turning off the MMA.Even Mike Tyson was shocked. And he once bit off part of a man’s ear.WHAT my mum would have found unforgivable about Strictly star Seann Walsh snogging Katya Jones is that it happened when Walsh’s girlfriend, Rebecca Humphries, was home alone on her BIRTHDAY.My mum would never have forgiven that kind of casual cruelty from some curly-haired love rat. And I suspect the great British public will feel the same. But what we call the Strictly curse is really just an office romance that spirals out of control.People get thrown together at work all the time. The dference is that a couple from the accounts department don’t usually spend hours every day rubbing up against each other perfecting their Paso Doble.But the intense, intimate physical contact of doing Strictly makes it certain the curse will strike again.The mystery is why Katya was never led astray by Ed Balls.FEMALE terrorist, married to a British jihadi, claimed a council breached her human rights by not giving her a new home after she turned down seven homes because they were not big enough or not in the right location.Kindly Brent Council also offered her £, to put down a deposit on a home of her own.Are we insane Our welfare state was built to care for the most vulnerable members of our society.Not creatures who would spit on our society’s grave.TINA TURNER is the only female performer who was hotter live than Blondie’s Debbie Harry in her pouting, heavy-lidded prime.So it comes as some surprise to hear Tina say that she never tried to be sexy on stage. “Fishnets are practical,” Tina says primly. “They don’t run. And leather doesn’t show the perspiration on stage or wrinkle. I only wore a mini-dress because everyone knows you can’t dance in a dress that goes past your knee.”OK, Tina, we believe you – even though your practical work clothes launched a million adolescent fantasies. And that was just in my house.DRESSED like a street-walking disco ball, Taylor Swt urges America to go out and vote Democrat in the American mid-term elections.I admire young Taylor but does it never occur to these celebrities that their smug self-importance might possibly be drumming up votes for the other side But where were your sensible shoes WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India. Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India.Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm must secure free trade deal
story: As the Prime Minister heads into the most signicant EU summit, she must secure the Brexit promised to the ­British public.Now is the time to deliver for the United Kingdom on the Conservatives’  General Election manesto promise to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade.It does not get clearer than the pledge: “We will no longer be members of the single market or customs union.”  Our manesto also promised that our laws would be made in the UK and interpreted by judges here, not in Europe. That’s why the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal was not right.Under such a deal, we would be required to follow EU laws under the EU rule book and we would still be subject to the European Court of Justice.We would be out of Europe, yet still run by Europe. Any proposal that is brought forward and put to Parliament needs to take back control of our laws and make sure the European Court has no say over us.  So what should Theresa May do  The answer, once again, is set out clearly in the  Conservative manesto.It says: “We will seek a deep and special partnership including a comprehensive free-trade and customs agreement.”  That’s why the Prime Minister should move on from her Chequers proposal and seek an advanced free-trade deal with the EU. A comprehensive free-trade deal, like the EU’s free-trade deals with Canada and Japan, is what our manesto promises require.Such a deal would ensure we take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade. It would honour the referendum mandate. It would be in line with our manesto commitments. And it would work for the EU too. The Government’s objection to this is the supposed dficulty of keeping an open border in Northern Ireland.For this reason, Government figures claim we cannot seek a trade deal with the EU unless this problem is solved. This is nonsense.Clear proposals have been set out by two former Northern Ireland Secretaries as to how a frictionless border can be maintained under a free-trade agreement. These proposals have been endorsed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis and Good Friday Agreement architect Lord Trimble.Moreover, former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith has set out how we can build on the system of joint border controls at Dover to avoid delays or friction at the UK’s borders — including in Ireland. This would work for the EU’s rules and ensure a positive future relationship going forward.This approach is not simply a bad use of taxpayers’ money. It breaks another manesto pledge.For our  manesto says “it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside our withdrawal, reaching agreement on both within two years” of our serving notice to leave the EU. In other words, by the end of March next year.So it is wrong for the Government to agree withdrawal terms without sorting out the full detail of our future relationship. A temporary fix does not honour the referendum mandate, it does not keep our manesto promise and it certainly fails to look after our hard-earned money.Moreover, would this temporary fix really be temporary  Just ask the people of Norway how such a deal turned out for them. In  they signed the European Economic Area Agreement. They were told by the EU their sovereignty would be respected. Yet  years later, this “temporary” arrangement has become permanent.Meanwhile, the cost has increased ten-fold and nearly , EU directives and regulations have been implemented through Norway’s EEA agreement.Our Government should fear to tread such a dangerous path. Voters will not tolerate any “temporary” arrangement becoming permanent. They would see it as a betrayal. People voted to leave the EU because they wanted change. They believed in Britain and the land of opportunity we can build. They voted to take back control of our laws, money, borders and trade.The Conservative manesto promised that we would leave the EU altogether. That we would seek a free-trade deal and a new national future.Now is the time for the Government to honour the referendum mandate and the Conservative manesto by seeking a free­-trade deal with the EU that enables Britain to become an economic powerhouse in the decades to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gangs put witnesses addresses and statements on twitter to intimidate them
story: The crooks are legitimately shown papers by their lawyers but then photograph them.Seven such statements about murders, knings and jail attacks have appeared on a Twitter account over the past year.A number have the hashtag #Snitchsquad.Some gangsters threaten witnesses from behind bars with smuggled-in phones.Crime expert Dr Simon Harding told Channel ’s Dispatches: “It’s a way of communicating they have power and authority over an area or iniduals.Police aren’t fully on top of this yet.”Abraham Badru, , was shot dead this year in Hackney, East London, nine years after he foiled a gang rape and helped jail the attackers.Mum Ronke believes it is why he was killed.The gunman remains at large.Det Supt Mike West said: “We need to improve our ability to scan for risk on social media.We’re seeing a transition from online content into offline violence.”Twitter refuses to axe the account outing witnesses.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: craig mackey 12 times more pension keith palmer
story: Deputy Met commissioner Sir Craig Mackey was accused of cowardice for locking himself in his car in the Westminster attack.Based on current earnings he could pocket up to £,-a-year, or £, a month, when he retires in December.Michelle Palmer, , is believed to be left with £, a year widow’s pension.Retired Det Chief Insp Mick Neville, who spent  years in the Met, said last night: “When the public look at PC Palmer’s bravery to stop a terrorist, then the contribution of Mr Mackey they will judge themselves who deserves the most pension.”Sir Craig, , was yards from unarmed PC Palmer, , when he was stabbed by jihadi Khalid Masood last March. Sir Craig was acting Met Commissioner at the time, earning £, a year.He will avoid any potential disciplinary action when he leaves after  years’ service.Insp Matt Webb, of the Sussex Police Federation, said his actions on that day were unforgivable and called for him to be stripped of his knighthood.Online pranksters altered a pic of Sir Craig getting his gong, replacing it with a white feather — a symbol of cowardice.Met chief Cressida Dick said: “Sir Craig had absolutely no opportunity to save PC Palmer.”And coroner Mark Lucraft QC told last week’s inquest Sir Craig couldn’t have done anything to stop the attack.Scotland Yard’s counter-terror chief Neil Basu branded the cowardice claims “abhorrent”.Sir Craig said he remained in the vehicle with two civilian colleagues because they had no protective equipment or a radio.He tried to get out of the car but was advised by an officer on guard at the site to leave.Michelle Palmer says her husband “was left at a vulnerable location with no protection to die.” He was carrying only a truncheon and CS spray.She should have received a lump sum of £, from the Met for his death. It is understood that they are considering a civil action for damages.Masood’s rampage left five dead. Friday’s inquest verdict at the Old Bailey found he was lawfully killed.A Met spokeswoman declined to comment on the pensions.LIONS led by donkeys. It was said of the Tommies in WW. And it’s true, it seems, for the frontline coppers of the politan Police.It was bad enough that “white feather” top cop Sir Craig Mackey locked himself in his car as Khalid Masood wreaked havoc around Parliament.But to see the size of his potential ­pension compared with the rank and file’s is sickening. Boardroom bobbies have closed ranks around Mackey, saying he had no choice but to keep out of danger. That’s probably what the rule book says.But real heroes act out of instinct, not self-interest.The contrast between Mackey’s actions and the bravery of PC Keith Palmer, or the off-duty PC Charlie Guenigault who ran TOWARDS danger in London Bridge, could not be clearer. The latter was awarded the George Medal this week. It’s now time to show our respects to Keith Palmer too, who paid the ultimate price that awful day.It is only right he is commemorated with a memorial in the Palace of Westminster — where we honour our best and bravest. He has earned his place amongst them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry meghan markle private jet lightning

title: democratic football lads alliance march
story: NewsDemocratic Football Lads Alliance march turns violent as supporters fight with policeSupporters of the far-right group were marching in central London before some of them started to push through their police escortsShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video march-democratic-football-lads-alliance-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA march by the Democratic Football Lads Alliance in central London spilled over into violent scenes today as protesters fought with police. Supporters of the far-right group were marching from Park Lane to Whitehall before some of them started to push through their police escorts. Dozens were seen fighting with police officers, with one seen threatening a policeman and screaming Ill kill you. Scores of police on horseback and wearing riot gear tried to control the swelling groups with police vans trying to block them in. Many DLFA supporters seemed extremely hostile to police, screaming at them for perceived inaction against paedos and grooming gangs.  The Mirrors Kevin Maguire said a DFLA executive member had promised , football hooligans would take to the streets. However, figures suggest around , people joined the protest with around , on a counter-protest opposing them. On Facebook , the DFLA organisers had said they were protesting ing jihadists, thousands of Awol migrants, rape gangs and groomers, and veterans treated like traitors. The DFLA have previously organised marches in Sunderland, Birmingham and London, with support of UKIP leader Gerard Batten and former EDL leader Tommy Robinson.  DFLA demonstrator Peter Mantell, , from Crayford, told the Press Association: I detest some of the people Im walking with. A lot of them hate people because of the colour of their skin. Im a lefty. But I believe we should have a voice against the people who want to hurt everyone and cause harm. Mr Mantell said he was a supporter of former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson.  Counter-protesters, representing groups such as Momentum and trade unions, managed to block the DFLA march route at one point. The counter-protesters, many of them masked, were shouting: Nazi scum off our streets and were kept away from the DFLA protest. A Momentum spokesperson said: Violent, far-right groups like the DFLA are a danger to our country. We cannot sit idly by whilst they mobilise. Scotland Yard said it had made only one arrest so far.

title: philip hammond faces embarrassing parliamentary
story: NewsPhilip Hammond faces embarrassing Parliamentary rebellionhe delays reduction in stake on fixed odds betting terminalsEXCLUSIVE: Sources say Philip Hammond is planning to include a date for the £ maximum FOBT stake when he deliverers his Budget later this monthShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsCampaigners – who warn more lives will be ruinedthe measures are delayed – are backing a Commons showdown that could see Mr Hammond’s Budget challenged "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Chancellor faces an embarrassing Parliamentary rebellionhe delays the reduction in stake on fixed odds betting terminals. Sources say Philip Hammond is planning to include a date for the pound maximum FOBT stake when he deliverers his Budget later this month. But he has yet to decide when the new rules will be introduced. And campaigners – who warn more lives will be ruinedthe measures are delayed – are backing a Commons showdown that could see Mr Hammond’s Budget challenged. Backbenchers could put down an amendment that would see it defeated and the FOBT rules brought in.  One source said: “The people getting organised are those he needs to keep onside. At the moment Tory backbenchers are willing to rebel at the drop of a hat, so he needs to be really careful. “He’s going to come under pressure from the backbenches as well as Number . They won’t want to go to war over a relatively small issue like this. After all, these are the MPs they need to keep onside for Brexit.“There’s no good reason not to do it, unless pressure from thegambling lobby is too much.” The Sunday People launched a campaign against the terminals dubbed the crack cocaine of gambling.Rules allowed customers to bet up to pound every  seconds. We fought to have the stakes reduced to pound. After years of pressure, the Treasury finally caved in. But they angered campaigners by appearing to delay the introduction of the new rules.  This followed pressure from the gambling industry who claimed the reduction in stakes would cost jobs and dent their profits. Bookies have claimed it will cost the Treasury poundmillion a year in lost tax and risk , jobs. Labour MP Carolyn Harris, Chair of the FOBT All Party Parliamentary Group said: “The Government must set a date in the Budget for when the FOBT stake is going to be reduced, and that should be April  at the very latest. “Anything after that would be indefensible and further evidence this Government cares little about improving society or helping vulnerable people. “The harm caused by FOBTs cannot go on.” LIVES ARE IN HIS HANDS By Liz and Charles Ritchie Founders of Gambling with LivesOur son Jack was just  when he took his own le almost a year ago because of a gambling addiction. It began with FOTBs while still at school.

title: theresa could clinch brexit deal
story: NewsTheresa May could clinch Brexit deal by Wednesday - with three more years in the EUEXCLUSIVE: The Prime Minister is on the verge of getting a deal ahead of a crucial vote by MPs but Brexiteers may not be happyShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsTheresa May could clinch a Brexit deal by Wednesday "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is within a whisker of getting an historic EU deal on Wednesday in time for a crunch vote by MPs next month. Butshe pulls it off at the European Council summit in Brussels it will tie us to Europe for three more years.That will infuriate Tory Brexiteers Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg , who will accuse her of selling out.And it will stop International Trade Secretary Liam Fox from concluding any lucrative overseas deals. Mrs May will present her plan to the Cabinet on Tuesday.Brexiteers Andrea Leadsom and Penny Mordaunt are expected to stay, but the PM fears Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey might resign.Mrs May’s Brexit guru Olly Robbins is in Brussels trying to persuade EU partners to accept our new offer.The PM is prepared to keep us in the EU customs union till Christmas  – but hopes to pull out earlier. That will keep a frictionless border between north and south in Ireland – the biggest bugbear of the talks. But Mr Rees-Mogg said the customs union idea must be “binned.” The exit agreement is  per cent done and a trading framework looks hopeful. If a deal is agreed, i’s will be dotted and t’s crossed at a further summit so that MPs can vote on it in November. The EU proposes keeping Northern Ireland in a customs union, but that was rejected by Mrs May and the DUP , which is propping up her government. DUP leader Arlene Foster said: “The UK is one nation. There should not be international-style borders within it.”A No insider said: “There must be a UK-wide solution. The PM will not accept carving off part of the UK for political expediency.” The EU’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier will tell Mrs May he is prepared to extend transition to December , . She will push for an earlier date – but the fact they both accept the same cut-off is the most positive sign yet of a deal. However, a source said: “The PM would never trap the UK in a backstop permanently.” If Wednesday’s talks fail then Britain will face a disastrous no-deal Brexit.

title: theresa walloped parliament over austerity
story: NewsopinionTheresa May walloped in Parliament over austerity as Jeremy Corbyn demolishes Prime MinisterMrs May was gutted, demolished, ruined, schooled – take your pick. This came about because Mr Corbyn attacked with questions on austerityShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionThis week Jeremy Corbyn did what he’s been threatening to do for a long time"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m not sure anything shows the gap between the Westminster and the wider country than Prime Minister’s Questions. In Parliament we imagine the whole nation grinds to a halt to watch the weekly grilling of the PM. People eagerly gather round radios, workers are called in from the fields, kids stop playing. But, as was pointed out to me this week,at pm on a Wednesday you really want to watch a competition between the red team and the blue team then BBC One’s Bargain Hunt is on. In some ways it’s a shame, though, because this week Jeremy Corbyn did what he’s been threatening to do for a long time. He completely took Theresa May apart. It has been a long road to get to this point for the Labour leader but worth the wait.  Manchester United’s Paddy Crerand once said about George Best that the star’s footwork left opponents with “twisted blood”. And that was the case this week. Mrs May was gutted, shydemolished, ruined, schooled – take your pick. This came about because Mr Corbyn attacked with shyquestions on austerity. And she has no answers. None. Zero. So she evades and ducks and es. To get an answer about austerity you need to talk to the police, firemen, teachers, NHS, armed forces, councils and ask how it’s going for them  Ask the people who are working but are still on their way to food banks how the end of shyausterity is coming along. I’ll save you a bit of time – it’s not going well. Mr Corbyn said: “Poverty is up. Homelessness and deaths on our streets are up. Living standards down, public services slashed and a million elderly are not getting the care they need. “Wages have been eroded and all the while billions were found for tax giveaways for big shycorporations and the super-rich.” Hard to argue with that. Still, Mrs May insists it will soon be over. Rejoice!

title: vladimir putin ordered novichok assassin
story: NewsVladimir Putin ordered novichok assassin to murder British spy behind Trump sex dossierEXCLUSIVE: Alexander Mishkin, , used the alias Alexander Petrov for the failed hit on the double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury in MarchShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe target - Former MI spook Christopher Steele compiled Trump dossier "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVladimir Putin shyordered shynovichok shyassassin Alexander Mishkin to murder the British spy who wrote the sensational Trump sex dossier, claims a former top Russian spy. Mishkin, , used the alias Alexander Petrov for the failed hit on the double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury in March. Accomplice Ruslan Boshirov was unmasked as GRU colonel Anatolly Chepiga and Mishkin’s true identity as a doctor in Russia’s GRU military shyintelligence emerged last week. He now faces allegations of plotting to use the same nerve agent on former MI officer Christopher Steele during a visit to Britain  months earlier. KGB defector Boris Karphichkov, , claims Mishkin was part of a GRU special ops group that slipped into the country in late February . According to information a GRU source gave him on a recent trip to Europe, they were here to kill Steele, , on the direct orders of Putin.  Karpichkov said: “I was told Steele was to be liquidated using the same stuff as the Skripals. The shyassassins shyinitially conducted surveillance both on Steele’s house in Farnham, Surrey, and at his London office. “The operation was aborted when they realised the house was guarded with a lot of CCTV. As they also quickly established he was not appearing at his office, they concluded it was too risky to carry out the operation.” The bid came after Steele was outed as the author of a -page dossier shyalleging Donald Trump romped with prostitutes during a  trip to Moscow. The file also claimed Trump had co-operated with Russia for years and warned compromising shymaterial on him could lead to blackmail. The US President has denied the claims in the “phony and corrupt shydossier” and called Steele a “lowle”. And President Putin wanted Steele dead for souring his relations with Trump and jeopardising dodgy shybusiness deals with people close to him.  Karpichkov said his source did not give him Mishkin’s real identity. But the former major in the KGB and its FSB successor added: “He shycontinually referred to him as ‘esculap’ – which is Russian for ‘clinician’. He said he was involved in some nerve agent research involving macaque monkeys.” This took place at the GRU’s secret labs in Kirov, known officially as the th Central Research Institute of the Ministry of Defence. Steele and Karpichkov were both targets on an eight-name Russian hit list revealed by the Sunday People earlier this year – which also included Skripal, . Karpichkov’s source said the Skripal strike was shyoriginally to be carried out by the FSB but the GRU stepped in after winning a power struggle.He added: “The FSB have more field knowledge and expertise to carry out such sensitive missions. But the GRU convinced Putin its operatives should carry out the extermination of one of their own traitors.  “That shows Putin was definitely aware of the operation.” The FSB transferred its hit squad to a second Russian exile living in Britain, former Aeroflot deputy director Nikolai Glushkov, . He was found strangled in his home in New Malden, Surrey, a week after the Salisbury shyattack. Glushkov had accused the Kremlin of murdering his friend, the Putin critic Boris Berezovsky. He claimed political asylum here after Russia accused him and Berezovsky, who died in , of a criminal shyconspiracy involving Aeroflot. But Karpichkov says Glushkov was really probing how Russian shyintelligence use Aeroflot as cover for overseas operations. The GRU has been led by Colonel-General Igor Korobov, , since February . But after its failure to kill Skripal in Salisbury and bungled operations where, he faces the sack. Putin is so furious with the GRU bungling he has ordered all future operations to be supervised by the FSB. Karpichkov said: “The most likely replacementis Lieutenant-General Sergei Gizunov. He’s Putin’s most trusted man in Russian military intelligence.” Gizunov was banned from the US by Trump’s predecessor, Barack Obama, as punishment for suspected cyber shyattacks in the  election. Steele’s company, Orbis Business Intelligence, was paid pound, to shyoutline Russian financial and personal links to Trump’s election campaign. The dossier stressed the allegations in it were “unveried”. According to court papers Steele filed in the US, the dossier was handed over “on a confidential basis in hard copy form” to British intelligence services because it “had implications for the national security of the US and the UK”. Last week Steele broke his silence with a swipe at Trump. He told Vanity Fair magazine: “In these strange times, it is hard to speak unpalatable truths to power but we all have a duty to do so.”

title: bride be 25 wakes up
story: NewsBride-to-be, , wakes up ‘entirely dferent person’ after her memory is wiped by rare brain conditionFran Geall, , from Falmouth, doesnt recognise her closest relatives or remember five years of university studiesShareCommentsByMike Smallcombe:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsFran with her brother, Joe, after her le was turned upside down "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bride-to-be woke up an entirely dferent person after her memory was wiped by a rare brain infection. Fran Geall, , was left unable to recognise even her closest relatives and friends after contracting auto-immune condition encephalitis - a condition where the bodys immune system starts attacking healthy brain cells. The marine biologist, from Falmouth, Cornwall, even lost all recollection of her pound, five-year university education and now has to learn how to live all over again.She told Plymouth Live even her niece and fiancee Staceys family were unrecognisable.Fran said: With people Im told Ive known for years, it can be like meeting them for the first time, which is really sad.  I also feel like Im meeting myself again, because I have absolutely no idea who I was before all this was. People say theres a new Fran, that Im a dferent person and theyre having to accept that. Im not so sureI like the new Fran, though. All I want is to get back to the old me, who achieved so much and built so many loving relationships. As ‘old Fran’ she completed an undergraduate degree in marine biology, before being awarded a Master of Science in sustainable agriculture from Plymouth University. Keen to work in ethical agriculture, in January she landed her dream job working as a business development manager for an oyster company in Whitstable, Kent.  In December  she also became engaged to marry the love of her le, teacher Stacey Tonkins, , who she had met at university over a year earlier. But her happiness was shattered in March this year, when she began suffering with migraines so crippling that she was forced to stay in bed for a week.She saw her GP and once visited AE , but doctors thought she had pulled a muscle in her neck, as she could not put her chin to her chest.Then, one morning, she began having a seizure in bed and it became clear something was very wrong - prompting Stacey to call an ambulance to rush her straight to Kents Ashford Hospital, where she was immediately placed in an induced coma. When she came around a week later, she felt like a completely dferent person.  Unable to read, walk or speak for several weeks, she is still having to relearn many basic le skills. Doing the simplest things, like using a computer or navigating around a supermarket, have now become very dficult, Fran said. But what is heartbreaking for me is that my intellect, which was like my superpower, is now gone, and all the years I spent learning facts and learning about the natural world has been wiped out like chalk on a blackboard. Despite having scant memories of her le before her brain condition, Fran said she still feels an instinctive emotional link to many of her loved ones, including Stacey, her parents and her siblings. But she has no recollection at all of her sisters-in-law or her niece and is now having to rebuild these relationships from scratch. She said: When Stacey and my family visited me in hospital, I knew instinctively that they were people I loved, but I couldnt remember anything about them, apart from very minimal, basic details. They would show me photos of old times together and it wouldnt jog anything - its like looking at someone s le. I couldnt speak, I couldnt walk and I had no idea who anyone around me was or what had happened to me.  Slowly, her faculties began to , although Fran could write before she could talk. I dont know why, but the first thing I was able to write down was my mums telephone number. I couldnt remember anything, but for some reason I could remember that, she said. The second thing I wrote was, things are a jumble. My friends and family tried to communicate by speaking and writing things down, too, but I couldnt understand anything. Things gradually improved when Fran was given a plasma exchange  days after being admitted to hospital, a procedure which replaced the white blood cells in her system that had been attacking her brain. After that, her speech recovered and she started writing a daily diary, although it did not trigger any memories. Discharged from hospital after five weeks, and determined to get back to normal, she ed to work. Within a few days, however, it became clear it was not going to be possible for her to stay when she had a major seizure. I realised then that my recovery would take a lot longer than I had imagined, she explained. The doctors have no ideaI will ever regain my memories, so Im living with the prospect of potentially having to relearn everything I ever knew. Fran, who once studied in Falmouth, now lives in the town to be near Staceys family, who are helping to support the couple. And Fran is putting all her energy into her recovery. She said: When Im out people will sometimes come up to me and say hello, as they recognise me from when I lived here before. Obviously, they dont know what Ive been through. I have no idea who they are, but still smile and pretend to know them. We only have a brief conversation, so theyre usually none the wiser. If I talk to anyone for longer, they can usually tell something isnt quite right, so I tell them what happened. Luckily, Fran has not lost her hunger for knowledge and is now reading up on everything she learnt at university. But she can only study for short periods, as the mental exertion can trigger seizures. As doctors have no idea what caused her encephalitis, a condition which still frequently baffles the medical profession, Fran often blames herself for what happened. “In a way, I feel like its my fault. Theres no logic to that whatsoever, butI tell myself that its just unfair, it puts me into a spiral of depression. Telling myself that there was some reason behind it lets me think that I can somehow get better and move on, even though no one seems to knowIll ever have my memory back. Although the future remains uncertain, Fran is delighted when people tell her they still see signs of the person she used to be. “People say that I used to crack a lot of jokes, and Im starting to do that again now. But I suppose when youre in a situation like mine, what  can you do

title: eugenie royal wedding cheeky savannah
story: NewsEugenie royal wedding: Cheeky Savannah Phillips stands on brides train in official wedding photographsThe seven-year-old bridesmaids mischievous move came after she had Prince George in fits of giggles during the ceremony on Friday afternoonShareCommentsByMark Chandler:,  OCT NewsSavannah put her foot on Eugenies train"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSavannah Phillips performed a cheeky move in Princess Eugenies royal wedding photos.Stunning official snaps of -year-old Eugenies marriage to Jack Brooksbank , , were released last night , a day after their Windsor Castle ceremony.One image showed the beaming bride and groom surrounded by their bridesmaids and page boys.And eagle-eyed royal fans have spotted Savannah appeared to be deliberately standing on Eugenies train.The mischievous seven-year-old, daughter of Peter and Autumn Phillips, is seen grinning at the camera as she places her left foot on the dress. Speaking about the newly-released official pictures, a palace spokeswoman said: “The couple are delighted to be able to share these images of their special day.”  In the stunning images, Eugenie can be seen grinning in her Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos wedding dress and Greville Emerald Kokoshnik Tiara.
