story: NewsFatima Whitbread to adopt a child aged  after being adopted herselfThe former javelin world champion ended up in a string of children’s homes and now wants to give something backShareCommentsByOlivia BuxtonJanine Yaqoob:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsIm A Celebrity.... Get Me Out Of Here contestant Fatima Whitbread arrives back with her son, Ryan "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOlympian Fatima Whitbread is aiming to adopt a child at  – to give something back after being rescued from her own horric childhood. The former javelin world champion ended up in a string of children’s homes after being abandoned as a baby and later raped by her mother’s drunken boyfriend. Her saviours were a love of athletics and coach Margaret Whitbread who took her under her wing at  and adopted her. Now Fatima – who has -year-old son Ryan – wants to give a child in need the chance of a better le, just like she had. “I have empty nest syndrome now because Ryan is at university,” says Fatima, who raised her boy alone after her estranged husband Andy died in .  “I have been thinking about fostering and adopting recently, especially now my son is moving away after he finishes next year. “I raised him to be independent and he can cook, iron and clean. It was always really important for me to be a hands-on mum. “I have a lot of love in me and it runs through everything I do. There is no iding line for me. “I always knew how lucky I was to find the love of the Whitbreads. I would happily give that same love and care to someone .” Found abandoned in a council flat at three months old, Fatima spent much of her childhood in and out of children’s homes and says she still suffers “crippling anxiety” from her time in care. Her mother later drted back into her le and social services arranged for Fatima to have visits to her home in the hope of a permanent reunion. But it turned into a nightmare and at the age of  she was raped by her mother’s boyfriend – while her mother held a kne to her throat to “quieten her down”. The turning point in her young le came when she met javelin coach Margaret, now , at her local athletics club and began spending a lot of time with the shyWhitbread family – eventually leading to her adoption at .  A settled and determined Fatima went on to compete in three Olympics, winning bronze at the  Los Angeles Games, and silver in Seoul in . In  she had set a world record and the following year in Rome became world champion and was voted the BBC Sports Personality of the Year. After her eight-year marriage to athletics promoter Andy Norman broke down and her career ended prematurely through injury, Fatima stepped out of the spotlight. But her appearance on I’m A Celebrity in  endeared her to a whole new legion of fans. Almost  million watched her come third on the hit ITV reality show. Her rollercoaster le has now led to plans to turn her inspirational rags-to-riches story into a film. “I have been working with two film scriptwriters,” she says.“Now it is up to them to get it written. But I’ve been with researchers for the past year and they have read my book Survivor. “Basically the script will focus on the first  years of my le and the  years I spent in children’s homes and the anxiety and isolation I suffered as a result.”She admits the insecurities ingrained in her over those years are never far away.  “I get crippling anxiety still and I have to try to combat that,” she says. “If I stay in my routine then I am not so bad, and so every day I go for a run or to the gym or I walk my dog. “If I don’t have a routine then I find it hard because as an athlete I was always training three or four times a day for  years.” Fatima has recently supported Barnardo’s adoption campaign, which aims to encourage more people to consider taking in vulnerable shychildren. If she gets the chance to adopt or foster, she says it will be a new chapter in a le in which she has triumphed over tragedy. And she’s not fazed by the prospect of adopting a child alone. She says: “My husband died when Ryan was nine and I have been a single mum ever since really. “I didn’t really want to introduce anybody into the equation and I was always a bit worried whether it would upset the apple cart. “It does work for a lot of people, but I have my own issues and I decided I would enjoy being a mum on my own. I have my family around me. Margaret and I have a special bond and I am very close to my brothers who were only two and four when I came into the Whitbread family, so they have only known me as ‘big sis’.

title: party girl who downed 10
story: NewsParty girl who downed  pints on night out reveals incredible results of going sober for OctoberDionne Mein, , said she feels like a new woman after she decided to go sober for October and is urging others to take part in the challenge.ShareCommentsByKim ReaderGrace Witherden:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDionne said tasks such as walking would leave her out of breath "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA party girl who lived on Chinese takeaways and would down up to  pints on a single night out has stunned her friends and family after taking part in the Go Sober for October challenge. Dionne Mein decided to take on the challenge after she ballooned to st, lbs and a size  after heavy boozing at the weekend and the odd glass of wine after work began to take its toll. Her friends never believed she would be able to keep up her sobriety for an entire month - but to their disbelief the pounds started to drop off once Dionne realised what a huge impact simple changes could have on her le. Determined to prove everyone wrong, the -year-old carer decided to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support and took on the challenge in October .  Dionne, who lives in Newcastle, managed to lose lbs. She said: Nobody thought I was going to be able to go sober for October. I was drinking a lot. I would come home after work and have a couple of glasses of wine and then drink loads of pints at the weekend. I was out partying all the time and then after a night drinking Id eat loads of takeaway. I decided to go sober for October to raise money for Macmillan and my mum doesnt drink so it was a little thing for her too. In just a month Dionne managed to lose half a stone but after October ended she began to slip into old habits, and the boozy nights ed. In January Dionne was determined to lose the weight for good and began to make simple changes to her diet and to start exercising. She said: People think you have to eat salad every day but I hardly ever eat salad and Ive hit my target. After losing a stone in a month, Dionne felt she needed another boost to keep the weight off. While looking for motivation on Instagram , the carer stumbled across a competition where all she had to do was like a video to be in with a chance of winning a personal training session - and won.Despite being so unfit that her first session made her physically sick, Dionne persevered and now trains at the Warehouse Performance Gym in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, for six hours a week. She now is a size eight and has lost a whopping five stone. Shedding her excess weight hasnt only improved Dionnes fitness and lowered her BMI from  to  - from obese to healthy - it has also boosted her self-esteem. Her newfound confidence has made Dionne feel like a new woman and she says without it she never would have met her supportive boyfriend Dean Irving, .  Dionne said: My weight had really started to affect me physically. Just walking around would leave me so out of breath. It even started affecting my job. I work in a care home and people rely on me for help but I was struggling with simple tasks like helping them put their shoes on. It was horrible feeling that way at such a young age. I was just  and I was struggling to help the elderly people in my care. The first session was so dficult that I vomited but I kept at it and what I did for that first session is like my warm up now. My personal trainer Nathan has been amazing. Without him Im sure Id still be fat. And losing weight hasnt just made me healthier, it has made me so much happier.  I was never happy before, people have always seen me as a bubbly person but I was just using that as a front. Whenever I went out, I was always the fat friend. If any guys came over theyd be coming to ask me whos your friend . All my friends are between a size  and . But since losing weight I am so much more confident, Im like a dferent person. If I hadnt gained so much confidence I dont think I ever would have met my boyfriend.

title: poor sell wedding dress buy
story: NewsI was so poor I had to sell my wedding dress to buy a typewriter – now Im a bestselling authorJessie Keane, , was born in a Romany caravan, left school with no qualications and spent years living on the breadline, until she had a big idea…ShareCommentsByRosie Hopegood:,  OCT NewsAuthor Jessie Keane has spoken about her new book"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Jessie Keane was three years old, her Romany grandmother read her palm. Tracing her fingers over the creases in her granddaughter’s tiny hand, she offered a prediction that would shape Jessie’s le: with a strong writer’s fork, Jessie would go on to be a well-known author. Jessie had been born in her grandmother’s traditional Gypsy wagon in her family’s back garden. Jessie’s mother had given up her traveller le to marry her father, a ‘gorger’and the family lived a settled le, though Jessie had always felt a strong connection to her grandmother and her Romany roots. One of her most poignant childhood memories was standing in the garden aged  watching the traditional burning of the wagon following her grandmother’s death. Sadly things went downhill following her grandmother’s death. Jessie’s much older brothers, who treated her poorly and were sometimes violent, embezzled money from her father’s engineering business, and the family went bankrupt.  ‘The stress was horrendous,’ remembers Jessie. ‘Suddenly, at , we had nothing. My father suffered enormously, and, in the midst of the bankruptcy process, he had a heart attack and died in front of me.’ Jessie and her mother moved to a run-down local authority flat on the outskirts of Southampton. The local kids teased her for being ‘posh’ and threw stones at the windows so that she was afraid to go out. The previous tenants had kept pets, and Jessie found herself covered in a mysterious red rash that turned out to be fleabites. ‘It felt like the bottom had fallen out of my world,’ she says. ‘I was close to my mum, but my brothers still visited frequently – I think my mum was afraid of these ft strapping men. I just felt like I had to get away and be free of it all.’ She landed a job washing dishes in a restaurant in London, and finished school with no qualications. Finding herself thrown into the seedy world of Soho in the s, Jessie was fascinated by the shadowy characters who frequented the area. She ended up marrying a musician at , orcing, and marrying again at . Without an O-level to her name, she found herself in a succession of increasingly depressing dead-end jobs. Over the years, Jessie worked as everything from a sweeper-upper in a hair salon to a bacon slicer in a deli, but she’d never once had a role she enjoyed, and the low salaries were barely enough to pay the bills. By the age of , she had hit rock bottom. Divorced and living in a freezing local authority flat, she was struggling to make ends meet. She hated her job in an electrical factory where she coiled wires for eight hours a day.  Just as her grandmother had predicted, her driving passion had always been writing and she had penned several romantic comedy novels that were now gathering dust.‘Those early books were hard work – they just didn’t seem to flow at all,’ she says.‘I spent donkey’s years slogging away at them, and though a couple of publishers said nice things, no one picked them up. That’s when I decided to write something entirely for my own amusement, a book I wouldn’t even send out to the publishers.’As she lay on the sofa one day, wrapped in a duvet against the cold, she flicked through the TV channels and, by chance, came across a film about the Kray brothers. She was drawn in at once: something about the murky underworld in s London appealed to her enormously. ‘That’s when I thought, “Wouldn’t it be interesting to hear a woman’s point of view, someone caught up in that criminal world ” An idea for a character called Annie Carter came to me, and I set about writing at once.’  For the next five months, Jessie worked furiously on her novel. Her le experiences gave her plenty of fodder for her writing: she knew all about the shady people who visited Soho, so she wove them into her tale of gangland London. Every evening after work, she’d stay up late – often past midnight – getting words down on the page. ‘Something had just clicked, and it was an entirely dferent feeling to when I was toiling away over the romance novels,’ she says. ‘I had an awful, horrible job but I’d get through the day because I knew after work I could just disappear into the page. I suppose it was isolating in a way because I’d spend every evening alone, and I kept myself to myself at work. But I’ve always been a pretty solitary creature.’ Jessie’s book was quickly starting to take shape, so she knew she needed to invest in a typewriter. But with no savings and bills to pay, Jessie had to find an imaginative way to cobble the funds together. She dug out her old wedding dress, took it to a second hand dress shop, and left with four crisp pound notes in her hand – just enough to buy a beaten up old typewriter.  After five months of tapping out , words a day, Jessie had a completed manuscript that she was surprised to find she liked. ‘I remember thinking, “This isn’t half bad.” At this point I decided to read my tarot cards, just like my grandmother had taught me.’ Jessie drew ‘double death’ from the pack, a sign that something monumental is about to take place. ‘I knew then, for absolute certain, that the book was going to be a big success – it was right there in the cards.’ She made a few copies of the , word manuscript she’d titled Dirty Game, and send it out to six agents. A week later, she received two offers from agents who loved the book and wanted to represent her. In the highly competitive world of publishing, this was big news, but Jessie wasn’t surprised at all: she’d seen it in the cards. ‘A couple of weeks after my agent took me on, she told me that a publisher had shown an interest, but warned me not to get excited because these things often came to nothing. Two days after that, she rang again and said, “I hope you’re sitting down, because you’ve got a three-book deal for a six figure sum!”’

story: NewsRegulators to crack down on  call firms charging up to £ for  secondsEXCLUSIVE: Greedy directory enquiry operators like Telecom have been charging extortionate "per call" fees, ripping off the publicShareCommentsByStephen Hayward:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDirectory enquiries firms are facing new pressure to provide a fair price for their service "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe number’s up for greedy directory enquiry operators who charge up to pound for calls lasting just  seconds. Phone regulators are set to crack down on the  services after protests at sky-high prices. Although many people now search the internet for numbers free of charge others – particularly the elderly and vulnerable – rely heavily on the services. Firms charge a “per call” fee which kicks in as soon as a customer rings them and then rises by the minute. With the average call taking  seconds to complete, charges soon pile up. For example The Number, the firm behind the market-leading  , charges pound. per call and then pound. a minute, which works out at pound.. Rivals Maureen charge the same amount for  seconds but Telecom can demand pound.. Charges are the same from landlines and mobile phones. However, some mobile providers make things worse by adding their own p “access” charge to bills.  Campaigners say the rip-off directory enquiry calls cannot be justied when similar services can be found for much less or nothing. The Post Office charges just pound for calls to its   number. The Number also provides a free service on   ,callers are willing to listen to an advert. The opening up of directory enquiries in  to new providers was meant to boost competition and cut prices, but bills soared. Operators have to register themselves and follow strict rules but there is no licensing system. Watchdog Ofcom has now launched a consultation on prices which is due to publish its findings by the end of the year. It could lead to a cost cap of pound. for a -second call – in line with charges of five years ago. David Hickson of the Fair Telecoms Campaign said: “Ofcom intends to give providers four months in which to make the necessary changes. It’s about time, operators have been ripping people off for far too long.”

title: vampire childs skeleton discovered stone
story: NewsVampire childs skeleton discovered with stone in mouth in ancient Roman graveyardA childs skeleton buried with a stone in its mouth was found by University of Arizona archaeologists in Teverinay, ItalyShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe skeleton was found in the Cemetery of the Babies "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vampire burial designed to stop a young child rising from the dead has been unearthed at a Roman cemetery. The ten-year-old childs body was found with a stone in its mouth, possibly out of fear the child would come back to le and spread an infectious disease such as malaria. The skeleton was uncovered at a commune in Teverinay, Italy by archaeologists from Arizona and Stanford universities. The bones are the latest in a string of unusual discoveries made at the Cemetery of the Babies since excavations began in . As well as dozens of childrens remains, archaeologists have found evidence of witchcraft including toad bones, raven talons and bronze cauldrons.  David Soren, a University of Arizona archaeologist, said: Ive never seen anything like it. Its extremely eerie and weird. Locally, theyre calling it the Vampire of Lugnano. Known as the La Necropoli dei Bambini in Italian, the cemetery dates to the mid-fth century when a deadly malaria outbreak swept through the area, killing many old and young. The bodies of the victims were buried at an abandoned Roman villa built at the end of the first century B.C. Until now the cemetery - which also contained the remains of a sacriced puppy - was believed to be designed specically for toddlers and unborn foetuses. A previous dig unearthed the body of the -year-old girl with stones used to weigh down her feet, a practice used in dferent cultures to keep the dead in their graves.  The discovery of the -year-old, whose age was determined by studying its teeth but whose sex is unknown, is the first evidence that the cemetery was also used for older children. It also provides evidence that the ancient community was worried about the undead. Soren added: We know that the Romans were very much concerned with this and would even go to the extent of employing witchcraft to keep the evil — whatever is contaminating the body — from coming out. The -year old was the first at the cemetery to be found with a stone in its mouth. Similar graves have been unearthed in other locations, including in Venice, where an elderly th-century woman dubbed the Vampire of Venice was found with a brick in her mouth in .  In  in Northamptonshire, England, a man from the third or fourth century was discovered buried facedown with his tongue removed and replaced with a stone. Other examples of vampire burials throughout history include bodies being staked to the ground through the heart or dismembered before they are put in their tombs. Archaeologists willto the gruesome graveyard next summer to complete excavations of the cemetery. Jordan Wilson, a doctoral student at the University of Arizona, said: Its a very human thing to have complicated feelings about the dead and wonderthats really the end. Anytime you can look at burials, theyre signicant because they provide a window into ancient minds. We have a saying in bioarchaeology: The dead don’t bury themselves. We can tell a lot about peoples beliefs and hopes and by the way they treat the dead.

story: NewsWorlds oldest woman, , reveals only happy day in long le that she claims is Gods punishmentKoku Istambulova claims to be -years-old and has spoken of a le of great hardshipShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video worlds-oldest-woman-aged--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who claims to be the oldest person in the world has told of the one happy day in her le. According to her Russian passport Koku Istambulova is -years-old, her birthday on  June  making her the oldest living person by more than six years. Many official documents were destroyed in the wars that ravaged her native Chechnya, meaning her age is impossible to very. If she is truly , then Koku lived through the toppling of Tsar Nicholas II in  and was  when her native Chechen people were deported en masse by Stalin to the steppes of Kazakhstan almost  years ago. “It was a bad day, cold and gloomy,” she said of the February morning in  when the entire nation was banished from their mountain homeland in the Trans-Causacus. “We were put in a train and taken … no one knew where. “Railway carriages were stuffed with people - dirt, rubbish, excrement was everywhere.”  Speaking in her native Chechen, Koku recalled young Caucasus girls dying when their bladders ruptured because they were too embarrassed to go to the toilet in the crowded, stinking trains. Koku added: “On the way to our exile, dead bodies were just thrown out of the train. “Nobody was allowed to bury the dead. “Corpses were eaten by dogs. My father-in-law was thrown out of the train in this way.” Earlier this year Koku said she had never lived a happy day in her le and was alive only through Gods grace. While she has again spoken of great hardship during the Soviet regime, Koku recalled a time when things looked a little brighter. Following Stalins death the Chechens  year exile came to an end, allowing many tohome only to discover their houses had been taken by Russians.  Undeterred and without the help of her lazy husband, Koku set about building herself somewhere to live. She said: Youre askingI had a single happy day in my le. “It was the day when I first entered my house. “It was very small and I stoked the stove with wood. “But it was my home. “I built it myself, the best house in the world. “I lived there for  years.” Kokus great granddaughter Medina, , now cares for the elderly woman.  She said that Koku feels the loss of her daughter Tamara, a mother of six and grandmother of , who died several years ago. “After her death Koku went almost blind, Medina said. “She hardly walks now. And when she recalls her daughter, my own granny, she gets anxious. “She cries many times a day as she recalls her daughter.” Things were very dferent for Koku when she was growing up. She claims to have never been to school, instead looking after animals, farming the family garden and caring for her ailing relatives. She said: “Father was ill, then mother was ill. Grandma was ill. “I was the oldest, how could I leave them ” As for romance, Koku married a younger man called Magomed who was chosen for her from another village. “I didnt know him at all,” she said. “But then I started to love him. “What  could I doI got married  “I had to endure. “He wasnt handsome at all.” Previously asked about the secret of her long le, Koku claimed it was Gods will and that long le is not at all Gods gt for me - but a punishment. She asked: Why did Allah give me such a long le and so little happiness  “I would have been dead long ago,not for Allah who was holding me in his arms. “It is hard to live when all who remembered you died long ago. And it is very scary to die, however old you are.

title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have title: loyalty only flows one way dismay as ms announces closure of local high street shop
story: The local economy has been dealt another blow with the announcement that MS is to close a High Street store.The shop, an anchor of the Kirkcaldy centre for  years, is expected to close early next year in a move that will affect  members of staff.The move is part of the ailing chain’s plans to bring the shutters down on more than  branches by  and follows on the heels of the closure of the town centre’s BHS, Next and Tesco stores.Bill Harvey, the manager of KirkcaldyAll, said MS shoppers would feel let down by the move.“I feel very sorry for their loyal customers who have stood by them through dficult times,” he said.“It appears loyalty only flows one way.”Shona Lawrie, MS head of region for Scotland, said the decision to close the flagship store had been “incredibly dficult”.“We know we have many loyal customers who will be disappointed by the news,” she said.“Closing and relocating stores is never easy but it is vital for the future of MS.”She added that the “dedicated colleagues will all move to nearby stores”.While no date for closure has been given, it is expected in the early part of , to dovetail with the opening of a new Glenrothes Foodhall.SNP MSP David Torrance said: “As one of the last remaining food retailers on the High Street, the loss of this store is yet another setback for Kirkcaldy.”Fe Council co-leader David Ross and Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath Labour MP Lesley Laird said they were seeking meetings with the firm’s senior management, as MS had given assurances over the future of the High Street store when it was planning to open a Foodhall at Kirkcaldy Retail Park.

title: Age proves no barrier to degree success
story: An Inverness grandfather proved that age is no barrier to academic success when he graduated from Inverness College UHI along with more than  fellow students.Hugh MacKintoshgraduated with a : BAin business and management with human resource management, following in the footsteps of his daughter Tara, who graduated from the same course in .Former Scottish Government business manager Mr MacKintosh, who lives in Inverness and enjoys spending time with his we Carole and -month-old granddaughter Ava, retired from his civil service role in  and had worked in Go Outdoors before deciding to study full-time."I never got the opportunity to go to university when I left secondary school in ," he said."I got married and had a successful career in the civil service for  years."But getting a degree was something I had always wanted to do. Retirement gave me the opportunity, but also the fact that the course was offered by a university on my doorstep."Mr MacKintosh believes his experience of working in business helped him and his fellow students through their studies."I really enjoyed the course," he said."My IT skills werenrsquot as hot as some of the younger studentsrsquo, but I was able to balance that out with my practical experience working in a business environment, and we all supported each other in dferent ways."I was always made to feel very welcome and my fellow students and tutors were so supportive."Irsquom happy in my retirement knowing Irsquove got my honours degree."That was what I was desperate to do."Also graduating was student representative Donna MacAngusfrom South Kessock, who achieved an HNC in events.She combined her studies with raising her five children and working in the food and beverage team at the college.She previously studied events and hospitality operations and is now aiming for a degree in events management."I have gained so much experience in dferent types of events and gained more confidence in myself and my abilities," she said."The course has provided a range of opportunities to gain experience in the workplace and itrsquos been wonderful through my studies to be able to volunteer at events including NessCon and Gok Wanrsquos Fashion Brunch Club."My time at Inverness College UHI has been amazing so far. The staff have all been fantastic and are always there to help when you need it."You are never alone ndash there is always someone there to help."As well as students celebrating the culmination of years of study, special awards were also presented at the ceremony.Among the recipients was Rachael Bewsfrom Evanton, who was named the collegersquos Alumnus of the Year.The award is given annually to a graduate who has made an outstanding contribution to their community or has made signicant achievements in art, science or business or in public or academic le.Having graduated with a first-class honours degree in business and management in , she has gone on to specialise as a digital marketing consultant.In February she founded ALICAS, a social enterprise based in Edinburgh which gts bespoke parcels of clothing to women who have fled abusive relationships.The packs are created using surplus retail stock which would otherwise be sent to landfill or incinerated.Ms Bews was awarded an RSE Unlocking Ambition Enterprise Fellowship, supported by CREATE, UHIrsquos centre for enterprise and innovation."The University of the Highlands and Islands played a formative role in sparking my passion for and experience of enterprise and entrepeneurship," she said."I couldnrsquot be more delighted to continue working with the university and CREATE on my new venture, ALICAS."With the continued support of the university and CREATE, it is now my ambition to create a scalable business model, designed to support as many women as possible."Professor Chris OrsquoNeil, principal of Inverness College UHI, urged the students to enjoy their chance to celebrate with their friends and family."It is my great pleasure to congratulate every single student graduating," he said."Graduation is a particularly special time as we celebrate and recognise the successes and achievements of our students in the presence of the people they care about most."It is reward and recognition of their hard work and commitment and I am very proud to share in this moment."I wish them only continued success as they bring to a close one chapter but embark on another, which Irsquom sure will include interesting and rewarding careers."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Charity festive outing set for a new home
story: A CHANGE of venue will not mean a dip in quality or a downturn in its fundraising muscle, those behind a musical festive favourite have insisted.Over the past  years the Highland Hospitalsrsquo Carol Concert has been a main seasonal fixture at Eden Court in Inverness.However this a year a clash of bookings will see it sht to the cityrsquos Macdonald Drumossie Hotel for an outing on Sunday, December .Concert committee chairman David Dean said: "Yet again, our choir of some  singers are poised to entertain a loyal audience and, with them, create a memorable afternoonrsquos Christmas singing."We much hope the change of venue to Macdonald Drumossie Hotel, with its free car parking and near guaranteed access whatever the weather will, once again, draw a substantial audience whose presence will raise a usual handsome sum of money to be donated to CLIC Sargent."The concert starts at pm on the day and tickets priced pound each are available from The Music Shop, Church Street, Inverness on  .Pre concert lunch will also be available at the hotel with tables bookable by calling   .Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Dawn ceremony plans for Remembrance Day commemorations
story: PIPERS and drummers will take part in a moving dawn ceremony during next monthrsquos Remembrance Day as part of a weekend programme of events in Inverness to mark the centenary of the end of World War I.They will gather at Inverness Castle on November  to play a well-known lament The Battlersquos Orsquoer at am to coincide with the signing of the Armistice agreement  years ago.The event, which will be among similar ceremonies across the UK, will herald other commemorations during the day including the main Remembrance parade and ceremony with a two-minute silence at am recalling the moment the guns fell silent on the battlefield.The events are being organised by the Inverness branch of the Royal British Legion Scotlandand Highland Council and will involve city churches and other organisations.Joe Davidson, branch chairman, said it will conclude a four-year programme of commemorations raising awareness of the global conflict in which millions died."I think people have been interested as it has grown over the past four years," he said."The numbers of people at each Remembrance Day have grown."I have also been impressed with the interest from schools now. Secondary schools are very much taking part in events and going on trips to the battlefields."Interest among iniduals has increased and prompted them look up their family history."The cityrsquos Armistice  programme will begin on Saturday November  when a memorial candle will be taken in procession from the cathedral to the Old High Church for a service.It will be the reverse of a similar parade four years ago marking the centenary of the start of the war when a candle was taken to cathedral where it has remained alight ever since.The event will begin at pm and will include a World War I horse-drawn ambulance plus serving military personnel and former service people,Although not part of the Armistice  events, wreaths will be placed the same day at the grave of Sir Anthony Miers who received the Victoria Cross during World War II and at the Commonwealth War Graves in Tomnahurich Cemetery as well as at the grave of Victoria Cross recipient Colour Sergeant James Munro in the Craig Dunain Hospital Cemetery.The following day, hundreds are expected to take part in the cityrsquos main Remembrance parade which will set off from Huntly Street at .am for the war memorial at Cavell Gardens.It will include representatives of the services, former military personnel, cadets, youth organisations, schools, politicians and civic and church leaders.City churches, which would usually hold their Remembrance services in the morning, have agreed to alter their times to avoid clashing with the commemoration which in other years has taken place in the afternoon.The service will include epitaphs read by Culloden Academy head boy Gavin Ryan and head girl Elle Fraser.An orchestral event will be performed by Ness Sinfonia in Inverness Cathedral at pm. It will close with a sunset ceremony including RBLS standard bearers, a Salvation Army bugler and a piper from the Inverness RBLS Pipe Band.The Inverness Choral Society will perform The Armed Man by Carol Jenkins at Eden Court on November  to commemorate the ending of hostilities.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: New festival promises a feast of folk talent
story: A NEW music festival will be added to Invernessrsquos already jam-packed programme of summer events next year.Organised by the same team that puts together the popular Groove dance music event The Gathering will concentrate on more traditional sounds when it comes to the cityrsquos Northern Meeting Park in June.Billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish talent Tide Lines, a band that has already racked up more than three million steams for their singles online, have been confirmed as headliners.They will be joined on Saturday, June  by The Vatersay Boys, Elephant Sessions and three-time winner of the Scots Singer of the Year title and BBC Radio  Young Folk Award winner Siobhan Miller.The day will also feature performances by bands Torridon and Hograve-rograve, along with Moray musician Calum Mackenzie Jonesrsquos The Trad Project.The City of Inverness Youth Pipe Band will formally open proceedings in true Highland style.Aiming for a family-friendly feel organisers say that, along with the musical line-up, the day will also include a showcase of the finest craft, food and drink suppliers from across the region.Organisers say a full range of participants will be announced shortly, but bars at the event will feature exclusively Highland and Scottish-based craft suppliers, with the Black Isle Brewery providing the draft beer and Tomatin Distillery official whisky partner at the main bar.Other breweries and distilleries will be showcased across the festivalrsquos second bar.Promoter Dougie Brown said: "We are delighted to be launching a brand-new city centre event for Inverness and hope The Gathering becomes a permanent fixture in the Scottish event calendar."We have a wealth of musical talent and incredible food and drink producers across the Highlands and Scotland and through The Gathering we aim to bring everyone together and celebrate the very best our region has to offer."Tickets for the event went on sale today and are available online at www.skiddle or in person from Eden Court Theatre or the Ironworks in Inverness.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Sights set on new Loch Ness centre
story: MONSTER hunters will have somewhere new to rest their beady eyes next summer when a multimillion-pound visitor centre, cafe and craft shop opens its doors on the banks of Loch Ness.Restoration work has started at the site of a new development spearheaded by the boat tour firm Loch Ness by Jacobite.The complex is being built within the former Dochgarroch village hall overlooking the Caledonian Canal and Dochgarroch Locks.Managing director Freda Newton said it would be a place "for visitors and locals alike to gather, share stories, and learn about Loch Ness and the historic Dochfour Estate".She added: "Visitors will experience a new retail offer showcasing the best of what Scotland has to offer within a unique and eclectic environment."We are extremely passionate about promoting incredible local produce, committed local suppliers and the Highland way of le to visitors, made all the more fitting by the building itself, which has been a community hub for almost a hundred years."The facility is expected to open in May.The development will include a ticket reception and entrance hall, retail outlet, a -seat cafeacute built around a new central courtyard, and an external terrace overlooking the Caledonian Canal towpath and quayside. Morrison Construction is handling the restoration.Donald Mclachlan, managing director of the firmrsquos Building Highland ision, is delighted with the contract.He said: "It is always pleasing when a prestigious Highland client selects a local contractor to deliver their project."We look forward to working with the Loch Ness by Jacobite team and our proven supply chain in constructing what will undoubtedly be a fantastic facility for the local community and visitors to the Highlands."Councillor George Cruickshank, for Aird and Loch Ness ward, said the new centre "could only be a good thing".Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Street art call to transform ugly city wall
story: A COMMUNITY leader is calling for an ugly corner in Inverness city centre to be transformed by a Banksy-style street artist.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, would like to see the Crown Road retaining wall decorated with street art.The wall, which holds up Stephenrsquos Brae, previously featured mural  depicting images of city landmarks and its people including well-known tramp Forty Pockets.But they were removed two years ago because the images had started to fade and the  looked scruffy.Mrs Hayden is now mooting the idea of finding the Inverness equivalent of Banksy ndash the anonymous English street artist whose work features on streets, walls and bridges around the world.She was also inspired by painted gable ends on buildings in Glasgow and Belfast."It is only a suggestion," she said. "That wall is ugly. There must be someone out there who could transform it but we would not want to give someone free rein ndash there would have to be some control."But I think it would be nice to have images of Loch Ness, Nessie or Urquhart Castle, or perhaps other Highland scenes."We have had a tremendous tourist season. As it wanes and we go into the quieter months, it is time to get things done so we are all ready for another busy season next year."Mrs Hayden did not believe the cost implications would be too great."It would only take a few tins of paint and paint brushes," she said. "Maybe someone would sponsor it."The previous artwork was installed as part of a streetscape project programme to improve the city centre.It was created by Fe artist Mike Inglis after months of research, during which he spoke to a cross-section of groups and iniduals, drawing on their stories and experiences.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Striking designs released for new hydro power site
story: ARTISTrsquoS impressions have been released of a new Inverness hydro power scheme Highland Council hopes will generate "signicant interest" among visitors to the city.The council has submitted a planning application for an Archimedes screw-based water turbine at the Torvean Weir on the River Ness.The design will be capable of generating up to , kWh per annum and help to power the sports facilities and Highland Archive Centre in the Bught. Any excess power would be fed into the national grid to generate extra funds for the council.It is thought it could raise between pound, and pound, a year. And the structure in which it will sit has been designed to shelter people looking to visit its viewing area."This modern, innovative project provides an excellent opportunity for the council to generate income and renewable energy and make savings," said Councillor Allan Henderson, the chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee."It is a fascinating piece of engineering which in itself should be a feature of signicant interest and may hopefully inspire young scientists of tomorrow."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Thousands attend pride march in Inverness
story: IT wasinitially expected to attract several hundred people, but instead marchers turned up in their thousands.Proud Ness, the first major LGBT event to be held in Inverness for  years, has been hailed as a watershed moment.In the weeks beforehand, the planned event had hit national headlines as it became embroiled in controversy after a -name petition was submitted to Highland Council opposing it on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".But it was given the go-ahead and in a show of solidarity, supporters turned out in force to create a colourful human crocodile.They came with rainbow-painted faces, many carrying flags, some on roller skates, drag queens sparkling in their sequins and silver heels. chihuahas with rainbow collars, babies in buggies and senior citizens with placards.In an atmosphere of good humour and friendliness, they wended their way from Falcon Square and along High Street, past the Town House flying a rainbow flag and across Ness Bridge ndash while the back of the parade was still continuing to file into High Street.Actress Tilda Swinton and former Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale were among those spotted among the crowds.Politicians included Inverness MP Drew Hendry and Highlands and Islands MSP Rhoda Grant.NHS Highland, the police, churches, youth organisations and businesses were also among those represented.Although speeches were due to be given at Eden Court Theatre, contingency arrangements were quickly implemented to open the gates of Northern Meeting Park to accommodate the vast crowd whose numbers wereestimated at between  and .Church of Scotland minister Rev Peter Nimmo was given a rapturous response as he delivered his speech, describing the event as fun and educational.Mr Nimmo, the minister of Old High St Stephenrsquos Church in Inverness, said there were still taboos around sexuality and gender issues."I hope today is a signal to LGBT folks in the Highlands that you do have friends who care and who stand alongside you," he said.Afterwards, he said the response to his speech had moved him deeply."It was amazing to contribute even in a small way to Proud Ness," he said."It was a good-natured and enjoyable event - an important day in the le of my city of Inverness."It was amazing for me to be able to speak to a crowd of thousands about Jesus and how he offers Godrsquos love to everyone without exception."The response to my speech has moved me deeply. Many people wanted to speak to me ndash some were almost in tears."It clearly meant a lot to some people that a minister of the church would say the sort of things I said."James Mackenzie-Blackman, chief executive of Eden Court Theatre, also spoke about the sense of pride in attending the event with his husband and two sons.He felt "something extraordinary" had happened in the city and said it was not just down to the LGBT community but everyone who had contributed."We will not live with shame," he said."We will live with pride and will support all of the people here today in Inverness and the Highlands."Tweeting about the event afterwards, he said he felt humbled and believed it had marked a turning point for the city.NHS Highland chief executive Elaine Mead also addressed the crowd.The petition opposing the march was organised by Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland .He and other church members were at the side of the route of the procession with their own placards.Afterwards, heacknowledged the controversy had generated large numbers in support of the event."Obviously I have to concede it is likely that because of the petition many came out in force but I have no regrets," he said.Mr Morrison had previously raised concerns that there would be displays of lewdness but commended the event organisers."I will give credit where it is due," he said."I was very impressed there was nothing of the sense which are displayed in any of the other cities across the country."But I still disagree with it and scripture is against it."These marches are sinful. God regards these relationships as sinful."Following the procession, Eden Court Theatre hosted a range of stands with information and displays, plusworkshops.A spokeswoman for the Highland LGBT Forum said they were amazed at the wonderful support they had received from Eden Court, Highland Council, Equality Network, theresidents of Inverness and many others.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Top cop staggered over driving offences
story: A DRIVER clocked at mph in a mph zone on the A on the Black Isle was among those nabbed during a police clampdown on illegal driving.Police in the Highlands and islands dealt with  drivers over ious road traffic offences during the first week of the road safety initiative Operation Cedar .There was particular focus during the first seven days on the Ross and Cromarty area.Offences detected included driving under the influence of alcohol, speeding, driving without insurance and driving while using a mobile phone.Eighteen drivers were dealt with for speeding offences ndash including the driver exceeding the limit on the A on the Black Isle. A report will be submitted to the procurator fiscal.Five people were dealt with for drink driving. The others were caught driving while using a mobile phone, no insurance and no MOT.Chief Inspector Iain MacLelland, lead officer for the Highlands and Islands Operation Cedar said: "The fact that drivers from across the region continue to place the lives of themselves and other road users at risk while driving under the influence is staggering."From the weekend past, across the Highlands and Islands we arrested eight drivers for driving while under the influence of alcohol and one while under the influence of drugs. Some of these drivers were more than five times the drink-drive limit."These arrests demonstrate that some from among our communities have a clear disregard towards the safety of others and need to be stopped."The dangers of drink driving are well publicised ndash you are not only putting your own le and livelihood at risk but that of every other road user."We have seen too many lives lost following collisions and my message to people across the Highlands and Islands is do not tolerate drink driving."You can pass on any information you have on drink drivers by calling  ndash or  in an emergency. If you want to remain anonymous, you can also contact Crimestoppers online or by calling   ."The enforcement work in Ross and Cromarty this week has involved local officers and from roads policing responding to concerns in our communities on a range of road traffic issues."Where we identy drivers who present a clear risk to the safety of other road users, we will enforce legislation and remove vehicles from drivers."This enforcement work will continue across the Highland and island area as we work to challenge, educate, detect and reduce injury collisions. We look forward to updating you as this initiative continues to develop."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Treasure found in a 1 box of goods
story: AMATEUR antiques collector Simon Grech took a punt when he spotted a box of bric-a-brac at Dingwall Auction Mart on sale for pound.But the Highland Council community warden was stunned to find buried beneath the chipped crockery and tea pots a beautul slate box hand-made by a -year-old African prisoner more than  years ago while he languished in a camp during the Boer War.The artefact, which has the prisonerrsquos initials SJP Venter scratched on its underside and is inscribed with the name Bellevue Kamp and the dates  and , is being snapped up by a notable London specialist.The expert, who collects Boer War memorabilia, has offered Mr Grech pound for the box, which is engraved with a South African folk flower mot and topped with an intricate quail bird.Mrs Grechrsquos we Marianne, who traced details about the boxrsquos original owner, said it was a "really exciting find".She said: "Simon likes to visit the Dingwall Auction Mart because he collects and fixes clocks."He came home with this box and the prisoner of war box was stuffed inside. It caught my eye so we did some research and it seems to have been made by a -year-old prisoner who was locked up in the Bellevue Kamp for prisoners of war in Simonstown, South Africa, during the Boer War."But we donrsquot know what happened to him or how the box came to be in Scotland, and we would love to find out."The couple, who stay at Balnacraig Road at Dalneigh in Inverness, contacted The Anglo-Boer War Museum in Bloemfontein, the only museum in the world dedicated solely to the Anglo-Boer Wars of  to , and they gleaned some interesting information.A historian told the couple a large number of Boers were captured in the vicinity of the Brandwater Basin in July and August of .A quick run through the names on the Bellevue Kamprsquos prisoner database reveals that Stephanus Johannes P Venter, a -year-old man from the Wepener District, was captured at Fouriesburg in July .But the young prisonerrsquos fate may never be known because no more details are held.The historian described the item as "a beautul slate box" and said it had signicant historical importance.Mrs Grechsaid it was a good thing Mr Venter had scratched his name on the box."Irsquod never have tracked this poor young guy right down to the day he was captured," she said.Praising her husbandrsquos nose for buried treasure she said: "Hersquos done really well. Hersquos only been going to the auction mart for a few months, itrsquos just a hobby, but he came back with a painting of The Alps for pound which Irsquove had valued at pound."However, she said some of his other finds were rather more questionable."The other week he bought a piano. I said lsquothatrsquos great, how are we going to get it home rsquo."He said lsquowell it was only pound, I couldnrsquot resist itrsquo."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: aberdeens devlin and mackay steven called up to scotland squad for friendly with portugal

title: aberdeen couple to appear on tv reality show dont tell the bride1
story: What started off as a joke between a couple turned into three weeks of wedding planning on national television.Leanne, , and Calvin Davidson, , put their relationship to the test after taking part in the popular reality TV series Don’t Tell The Bride on E.The show sees couples awarded money to create their dream wedding, however there’s a twist – every detail must be organised by the groom, with no contact with the bride.The happy couple are keeping tight-lipped about the exact details of the big day, but did say the £, was spent on a “very Scottish wedding”.Calvin, a joiner, said: “The whole thing started off as a joke after the pair of us watched the advert asking for couples to apply.“It was just two weeks after our engagement, but we thought a free wedding would be ideal for us as we have a baby on the way.“To begin with, none of our family members wanted to be on TV and hated the thought of it.“Yet after a while my mum and all the bridesmaids got right into it and really enjoyed the whole experience.”Calvin added: “We sent in an application and video of the two of us in April and the next day we got a phone call to come down to Glasgow for an audition.“The whole process took about three months – we were absolutely buzzing when we were chosen.”Leanne, a mobile hairdresser, had to put her complete trust in Calvin’s wedding day choices, since they were not allowed to contact each other during the filming.Leanne, who is  weeks pregnant, said: “I had complete trust in Calvin to plan it all.“There’s always going to be hiccups on the programme, but because we’d been apart for such a long period of time we just didn’t care what happened on the day.“I would have done a lot dferentlyit was me organising the wedding.“It would have been a big sparkly, glamorous wedding and I wanted to get married in a church.“You hear that every time on the show, but it was such a good laugh.“I was shocked that the wedding dress Calvin picked was far better than the one I had selected for myself originally. He clearly knows me better than I know myself.”The Bucksburn couple said the Granite City would feature prominently in the show, which airs later this month.Calvin said: “We filmed a lot in Aberdeen. We went to Codonas where Leanne and I liked to bowl. So we filmed some scenes with us bowling and on the beach front. I think we have done Aberdeen proud by representing it.”Calvin said the entire experience was “trickier” than it looks on TV, but said it was “amazing”.He added: “You have to figure out what to spend the £, on and having no contact with Leanne was tough.“But we had such a good laugh even though it was stressful – it was an amazing experience.“All I can say is that it’s going to be a very Scottish wedding.”The couple are eagerly awaiting the arrival of their first baby and also the premiere of their episode.Leanne added: “We’ll be watching the episode for the first time when it’s aired, which is exciting but nerve-wracking.”The episode will air on E on October  at pm.

title: aberdeens dancing water fountain display officially switched on1
story: The water fountain at the heart of Aberdeen#s Broad Street has been officially switched on.With around  illuminated jets of water, the fountain#s designers say it is capable of limitless patterns and sequences.The feature forms part of the £. million development in the area, which includes a raised grass area, trees benches and a flexible event space # which has already been used for a number of events including Celebrate Aberdeen.Councillor Ross Grant said: “Overwhelming feedback from the public during the City Centre Masterplan consultation was for more pedestrian-friendly areas.“As the east end of the city centre continues with its transformation the new shared space on Broad Street, complete with enhanced public realm, is now a more al, attractive and cleaner place for people designed to encourage people to linger longer which is also a fit for purpose event ready space to accommodate Aberdeen’s growing programme of events and festivals that take place year round.“The Broad Street layout is the first of its kind in the city and, as a new space for the city centre, we’d ask all users of Broad Street to continue to be considerate and mindful of all other users.”Sustrans Scotland community links manager Dave Keane said: “Creating safe and attractive spaces to walk and cycle is at the heart of our Community Links programme and we are proud to have supported the changes made to Broad Street as part of the City Centre Masterplan.“By creating a street which prioritises people on foot and bike, Broad Street becomes a more attractive place for everyone, that will improve health and wellbeing, increase footfall for local business and bring communities together.”Muse Developments regional directorSteve Turner said: “The redevelopment of Broad Street is the latest phase of a remarkable transformation of this city centre location.“The new open pedestrian-priority design complements Marischal Square which is already proving to be a vibrant and popular civic space.#I believe this will further enhance the City Centre Masterplan ambitions to bring le back into heart of Aberdeen.”Speaking last month, Peter Dawson, director of fountain designer OCMIS, said the city of Aberdeen was one close to the company’s heart after previous projects in the region.He said: “The fountain in Aberdeen is really good because it’s intensive and exciting.“We were discussing the idea back in  so it’s been a long time in inception.“It has  jets and each nozzle can be programmed to perform a dferent height or sequence so the options are limitless.“Sometimes with fountains the public can get a bit bored when the sequence is the same, it can become part of the background, but this way the council can keep it interesting.”

title: ball gets money whirling in
story: More than £, has been raised for charity from a ball.The money was made at CLAN Cancer Support’s Wanderlust Ball, held on Saturday at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre .A total of  guests attended the event, which was organised in support of the north-east-based cancer charity.All funds will go towards providing support services to people with cancer and their families.Fiona Fernie, head of income generation and business development at CLAN, said: “We are absolutely delighted that the Wanderlust Ball has been a big success.“CLAN celebrates its th anniversary this year and the success of the evening and the totals raised show the impact we have on people’s lives.“I’m very thankful to everyone who supported the event and helped to raise such a fantastic total.”

title: focus on female medics
story: A talk is to be held discussing the first female medics to graduate from a city university.The informal event will feature presentations from students and staff from Aberdeen University.Taking place on October  in the Suttie Centre, part of the Foresterhill campus, the talk will discuss the changing medical student population and the careers of the first five female graduates from the university.Speakers include third-year medical students Rosannah Jackson and Claire Repper, Professor Rona Patey and Dr Stephen Lynch.The event is free and does not require booking.The talk is part of a series called Cafe Med and the programme of future talks can be found online at bit.ly yjlOi

title: green light for meetings over schools
story: Councillors have moved forward with plans to improve educational outcomes for children.Members of Aberdeenshire Council’s education and children services committee have given the green light to assess all schools, looking at the condition of buildings, number of pupil places required and staffing needs.Councillors will contact the chairs of all parent councils and then early next year will set up engagement meetings in all council areas to give as many parents, carers, teachers, and other school staff a chance to have their input into the next steps.Findings from the engagement will be taken back to committee later next year and may include proposals for building improvements, mothballing and extension works.Chairwoman of the committee Gillian Owen said: “Both nationally and globally it is recognised parents are the single most important influence on their children’s development, learning and achievement.“We also recognise that the school environment our children and young people enjoy and the management of this is vitally important too.“The reports discussed share that same end goal: to support and improve educational outcomes for children.“This isn’t simply about looking at numbers but assessing the needs of children and young people within our communities, and working directly with parents, carers and teachers to ensure the plans we put in place best meet those needs and aspirations.”

title: its time to send us your tokens
story: More than  groups have tossed their hats into the ring in the hope of bagging a share of £,.Community organisations, sports teams and social clubs are among the  who are eagerly collecting tokens.People have been getting creative with their ideas to push for as many tokens as they can get and many have taken to their social media to appeal to family, friends and fans. Others have placed a special collection box at their receptions where visitors can drop off tokens.Generous members have even volunteered to pick up the tokens from homes.This year non-for-profit organisations are looking to spend their winnings on a range of things.Torry Memories and Heritage Society hopes to spend any share on a heritage subscription for its members.Some sporting teams like Grampian Flyers Basketball Club and Lewis East End Youth Football Club are looking to score to pay for new equipment.And the rd Aberdeen Girls’ Brigade is hoping to celebrate its th anniversary by putting the money towards participating in a special sleepover in the Glasgow Science Museum.Don’t miss your chance to snag the last bumper token in today’s Evening Express.Today’s token is worth five in the CommunitEE Chest.Once you have collected all your tokens, fill in the form below and get them sent in to the Evening Express by Monday November .

title: new bikes for sports centre
story: A city sports centre has invested £, in new equipment.Aberdeen Sports Village has created the new group cycle studio at the fitness facility at the Linksfield Road centre.The investment sees the arrival of  state-of-the-art Technogym bikes, which will allow the number of Les Mills spin classes at the venue to grow.As a result, more than  instructor-led and virtual classes will be delivered this month, with the new timetable launching on Monday.Health and fitness development manager at Aberdeen Sports Village Kris McIntosh said: “This is a signicant investment for Aberdeen Sports Village and it is a superb addition to our facility.“Spin is one of the most popular class activities, therefore creating a dedicated spin studio and investing in staff training demonstrates that we are committed to listening to our members and delivering what they want.”

title: north east academy womens football team receives 800 kit donation
story: A north-east football team looks poised to join the “sundae league” after scooping a donation from a north-east ice cream maker.Alford Academy’s women’s side has taken delivery of £ worth of new strips which have been designed and paid for by Mackie’s.The firm made the gesture after learning that the women’s and girls’ sides were sharing kits.Head of PE Brian Cruickshank welcomed the “very generous” contribution.He said: “Just having the one set wasn’t ideal, it meant the girls couldn’t train or have matches at the same time and it was an all-round inconvenience.“With this very generous donation we don’t have to worry about these logistical complications.”

title: north east energy firm teams up with clan to celebrate charitys 35th anniversary
story: An energy firm has teamed up with a north-east charity to celebrate its th year.Oil and gas company Hydrasun pledged its support for the new CLAN Cancer Support campaign Think Cancer Think CLAN over the next year. The project will explore the stories behind the people who have used the service.CLAN CEO Colette Backwell said: “Thanks to Hydrasun’s support, we aim to reach even more people who can benefit from our support.”Bob Drummond, CEO of Hydrasun, said: “We are delighted to enter into this new partnership with CLAN Cancer Support and to be able to support their awareness campaign and to help them reach even more people who can benefit from their support in the future.”

title: study into arthritis treatment
story: A team of north-east researchers will lead a study into pain caused by arthritis.The Aberdeen University academics launched the research yesterday to coincide with World Arthritis Day.A total of , people across  hospitals will be recruited to be a part of the new study, which will test the effects of new therapies into psoriatic arthritis.Lasting for five years, the research will track the progress of participants while using the new treatments in comparison with typical NHS care.Dr Gareth Jones, reader of epidemiology, said: “The combination of arthritis and psoriasis can greatly reduce an inidual’s quality of le, and can affect all aspects of their le including their mental health and work.“These drugs have proven to be hugely beneficial in treating rheumatoid arthritis so there is great interest in being able to study their benefits in psoriatic arthritis.”

title: tea parties planned to ease loneliness among older generation
story: A community organisation is urging vulnerable people to get in touch in an attempt to tackle loneliness.Froghall Community Centre, on Powis Place, is to launch Ina’s Tea Parties next month in the hope of increasing inclusivity in the community.The events have been made possible after a successful application to the Health Improvement Fund.Linda Presslie, treasurer of the centre, said: “It was a member of our senior club, Ina Beattie, who came up with the idea of having tea parties for those who feel isolated.“We wanted to do something to help with the health and wellbeing of people in the community, so we discussed the idea of a tea party.“We will serve the tea in china cups and saucers and I will be making the cakes and sandwiches.”The event, which will be invitation only, will be aimed at older people, those with mobility or mental health issues.Linda said: “People who don’t manage to get outside often worry they won’t have enough to say, and so we will have our volunteers to keep things moving.”However, staff and volunteers at the centre have concerns that word of the social event will not spread.A Powis Place resident said: “Older people, or those who have not attended any of our clubs before, may not come forward to ask for an invitation. They may not even find out about it.“We would like anyone who hears of this event to think of a friend or relative who would be a good fit for our tea parties.”Linda can be contacted on  .

title: youtube snares north east pervert posing as girl1
story: A pervert who set children sexual dares and challenges with the promise of getting them YouTube subscribers has been told it’s “almost unimaginable” he won’t be jailed.Rory Gill posed online as a teenage girl and engaged with male children, some under the age of , on YouTube and Omegle.The -year-old, who even livestreamed videos of children performing sexual acts online, was caught after a YouTube moderator flagged his behaviour to police.Depute fiscal Jamie Dunbar said police received intelligence from a “YouTube moderator” and obtained a search warrant for Gill’s address on Burnside Road, Tarland.Police seized computer equipment and discovered  indecent videos of children with a total playof  hours and  minutes.A total of  of the videos were assessed as the worst category A.Mr Dunbar said: “The accused would use the social media  where he would pretend to be teenage girls.”He added Gill would “communicate in a sexual manner with the boys, send pornographic images to them and induce them to engage in dares or challenges”.Mr Dunbar told the court the challenges were of a sexual nature, some involving “removing clothing”, “dancing naked”, and performing sexual acts. InGill offered to show the boys sexual images or get them more YouTube subscribers.Gill pleaded guilty to acting as a female and sending written sexual communications to male children, some aged between  and  and some under  and requesting they perform ious sexual acts between January   and November  .He further admitted taking, or permitting to be taken, indecent photographs or pseudo-photographs of children, and also distributing or showing images.Defence agent Liam McAllister said his client, who has no previous convictions, had pled guilty to “incredibly serious charges”.He said Gill had taken “full responsibility for his actions”, adding: “There are signicant issues about his background and personal and family issues that will be explained in a social work report.”Sherf William Summers told Mr McAllister: “Your client is going to jail. The question is not , but for how long. It’s almost unimaginable that the court could deal with this in any way other than imposing a custodial sentence.”Sentence was deferred on Gill, who was released on bail, until next month for reports.

title: devastating 18 second pro debut win for aberdeens docherty
story: Aberdeen super-middleweight John Docherty has made a sensational professional debut with a knock-out after just  seconds.Docherty, who trained at Byron Boxing ABC before turning pro, stopped Jordan Latimer with a barrage of punches straight from the bell at the  Radio Arena in Newcastle.Latimer went into the fight with a record of two wins from two fights but was left so shaken by Docherty#s barrage that he nodded to his corner to throw in the towel.Commonwealth bronze medallist Docherty signed for Eddie Hearn#s Matchroom Boxing having ed from the Games in Gold Coast.The -year-old southpaw was set to make his debut on the undercard of Anthony Joshua#s heavyweight world title defence last month but the paperwork was not processed in time.However he announced himself to the paid ranks with a devastating debut.

title: docherty spars with champs ahead of debut
story: Aberdeen-trained boxer John Docherty has been mixing with world champions ahead of his professional debut.The -year-old Commonwealth Games bronze medallist will tonight make his bow in the paid ranks against durable Spaniard Alejandro Mostazo at theRadio Arena, Newcastle.Following his medal success at the Gold Coast Commonwealth Games earlier this year, Docherty signed up with Eddie Hearn’s Matchroom Boxing, who also oversee undefeated heavyweight world champion Anthony Joshua.In preparation for his debut at super middleweight Docherty has been sparring with WBO world middleweight champion Billy Joe Saunders and trained alongside former three-weight world champion Ricky Burns.Docherty also came close to making his debut on the Joshua undercard in September in front of an , crowed – only for paper-work to derail that dream fight.Byron Boxing Club-trained Docherty said: “I can’t wait to make for my debut as I have been working so hard towards that.“I have been sparring with Billy Joe Saunders who is a world champion and did four rounds with him. Saunders wants to spar with me again as I am a southpaw.“It was a - spar and I wanted to see where I was.“That showed I was well on track and I will be more than ready for my debut in Newcastle.”A multiple Scottish champion and British champion at youth and amateur level, Docherty could have made his debut on the same Wembley bill as Anthony Joshua’s successful IBF, IBO, WBA and WBO world heavyweight world title defence against Alexander Povetkin on September .He said: “It was only two days before the Wembley bill when Eddie said I was going to be added to the undercard.“We had to get my medical done first and it didn’t end up coming off because we ran out of time.“I didn’t go to the show. I was too disappointed to sit and watch it thinking that I could have been at that boxing bill. Instead I just trained hard at home.”Having ed home with bronze from the Commonwealth Games in April this year, Docherty was at a crossroads in his career. As part of the Team GB podium scheme, he was viewed as a potential medal contender at the Tokyo Olympics in .However, he opted to sign on with Hearns and relocate to St Albans to train with Tony Sims, who previously trained Joshua.Docherty said: “I hadGB on the phone saying we will pay you extra to stay on towards the Olympics.“I was number one in Britain so I was guaranteed to go for Olympic qualying so that was a big decision.“My dad and my amateur coaches Kevin and Tonyand myself discussed it.“It was a hard decision and took me a few weeks to come round to it as I didn’t know whether to stay amateur or turn professional.“Everyone wants to go with Eddie Hearn and Tony Sims doesn’t have much fighters but he said he definitely wanted me.“They said they will see what happens at the Commonwealths and then we will take you on.“I was very focused on the amateur game and the Olympics.“I went to meet Eddie Hearn, he made me a good offer where the money was right and promised me big fights on big stages.“He sold it to me.“British level at my weight I can beat them now – never mind in a year and a half or two years time.”Spaniard Mostazo, , Docherty’s opponent tonight, boasts a record of three winsand five defeats .“I feel strong, great and everything is going well,” said Docherty. “I can’t wait for my first professional fight.”
