title: your-chance-to-win-gift-vouchers-by-tasting-food
story: The university is on the lookout for more than  new food tasters to take part in the taste  run by its Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation.They get the chance to try new Scottish food and drinks products, including cakes, bakery, dairy, ready meals and meat products, as well as new food products that have yet to launch.The food  currently attract many retired people from the community, as well as all those who are available to attend the university during weekdays.However, due to a new large-scale project, there is a need for hundreds of new ists who have an interest in food and enjoy sharing opinions on the subject.Vanessa Durney, a food  member from Musselburgh, said: ldquoIrsquove really enjoyed taking part in taste trials as we get the opportunity to taste premium brand products, basic ranges and new products that are in the development phase.ldquoThe taste trials take part in the universityrsquos sensory evaluation suite and we donrsquot see any labelling, branding, production information or packaging. This helps ensure there are fewer influencing factors and that we provide an unbiased response. Peoplersquos palate and opinions can dfer wildly, so the conversations after the tastings are always very interesting.No previous experience is necessary to take part in the sessions but all participants should be over  and should not have any dietary restrictions or food allergies. They are rewarded with a choice of gt vouchers from either John Lewis or Amazon ndash between pound and pound ndash as a thank you for attending.Panels run throughout the year and ists are free to apply for as many or as few sessions as they wish.For more information or to sign up, email Lucy MacLellan at consumer@qmu.ac.uk

title: tranent-woman-caused-disturbance-after-accusing-girlfriend-of-being-unfaithful
story: Jacqueline Stevenson behaved aggressively, believing that her partner had not been faithful during their relationship.Stevenson grabbed her belongings from the couplersquos home before the pair began struggling with each other as her partner disputed the ownership of the items being taken.Following a physical struggle between the pair, neighbours stepped in to break it up before police were called in.Stevenson pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing, acting in an aggressive manner and struggling with the woman at an address at Potters Path, Tranent, on May  when she appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Fiscal depute Anna Robertson told the court that Stevensonrsquos partner was within her Tranent home when she received a phone call which ldquoenraged Stevenson at about .am.The fiscal said that Stevenson began ldquoshouting and swearing before ldquoaccusing her of cheating.The argument between the pair lasted a number of hours and ldquocame to a head when Ms Stevenson picked up items from the locus and began to leave.Her partner was said to have followed Stevenson ldquocrying and saying the items were hers before a struggle ensued between the pair.Neighbours watched on as the couple argued before one neighbour ldquoattempted to break up the struggle.Police were subsequently called in to deal with the situation and Stevenson, , was arrested and charged.Defending solicitor Rebecca Weissgerber said that Stevenson was currently living with her mother and was unemployed.Ms Weissgerber added that the couplersquos relationship was ldquonow at an end after there had ldquobeen some dubiety as to whether [Stevensonrsquos partner] had been faithful.Sherf Adrian Cottam acknowledged Stevensonrsquos lack of previous offending and decided to issue a fine of pound to mark the offence.Sherf Cottam also agreed with the Crownrsquos motion to hand Stevenson a two-year non-harassment order banning her from contacting or approaching her former partner for two years.

title: new-flats-at-former-cockenzie-boatyard-welcome-first-tenants
story: LAR Housing Trust has built  new flats at The Boatyard in its first-ever design and build development.The Boatyard is made up of four onendashbedroom apartments,  two-bed apartments and five two-bed deluxe apartments, all of which have been filled.Mr Stewart said: ldquoThis is an absolutely cracking housing development which adds to the mix here in Cockenzie. Itrsquos on a spectacular site overlooking the harbour.ldquoI was here at the very beginning as they were building and was impressed by the amazing views ndash some of the tenants are going to have a spectacular sight when they open their curtains in the morning.ldquoI want to ensure that every part of Scotland benefits from what is the biggest housing programme in decades. Obviously, East Lothian is a place which will benefit from the amount of investment wersquore making.As a tribute to the former boatyard at the site, a stone carving ndash produced by local sculptor Gardner Molloy ndash has been installed on the harbour-facing side of the building.Andrew Robertson, chairman of LAR, highlighted the carving as ldquoabsolutely critical as it tied into the community that used to work there.He told the Courier: ldquoThis sense of community has been very important here because the design reflects the fishing village boatyard nature of the site.Mr Robertson hoped that, in future, there could even be some kind of small ldquomaritime museum there to ldquoreflect some of that boatbuilding history.Ann Leslie, CEO of LAR, also confirmed that LAR was building another development at nearby Dolphingstone, which will add to the existing East Lothian LAR developments at Macmerry and Pinkie Mains.Mr Robertson said that the majority of new tenants at The Boatyard had come from the local area, adding: ldquoItrsquos lovely. Itrsquos not been explicitly the case. People could have come in from outside.ldquoThe fact that we are actually providing a vehicle for continuity of community is very satisfying. But we wouldnrsquot want to exclude other people who are in need.More than  people from the local area applied for the homes before they had even been advertised, but Mr Robertson was keen to point out that the need for affordable housing was not desperate.ldquoI donrsquot think therersquos a desperate need but itrsquos an expanding local authority economy, he said.ldquoTo call it a desperate demand may be slightly overstating it. There are parts of the country where you could go where there is a desperate need for social housing.ldquoThere is social housing here and therersquos a responsible housing department and good housing associations and we are working very much as part of that mix. I donrsquot think anybody is talking about things being desperate.ldquoThere is a need and itrsquos being met in a controlled and effective way.Ward councillor Neil Gilbert was also present at the handing-over of the keys and told the Courier that the development was ldquoextremely important.He said: ldquoThis is hopefully a step to a lot more of these properties being provided. The level of rent that these facilities house is what East Lothian needs.ldquoThis is a step in the right direction but letrsquos hope itrsquos a springboard for a lot more.ldquoWe need as many affordable properties as we can. When I say affordable, I mean social-rent-affordable. The more we have of those the better.

title: union-launches-petition-in-bid-to-save-toilet-attendants
story: The union has thrown its weight behind staff who are based in public toilets around the county.And it has warned that axing the full-time workers would let standards in the facilities fall and make them a target for ldquovandalism or drug use.East Lothian Council said in July it was considering extending its team of ldquomobile toilet attendants to replace permanent on-site attendants in a bid to save pound,.There are currently seven permanent attendants covering public toilets in Haddington, Musselburgh and North Berwick. In addition, there are half a dozen mobile attendants who provide cover when the permanent attendant is not available.The Unite Scotland petition, which has been launched online at ipetitions, says: ldquoPermanent toilet attendants keep our public toilets safe, clean and accessible for everyone in the community, as well as for tourists.ldquoWithout a permanent attendant to keep watch, it is likely that standards will fall and the toilets could become a target for vandalism or drug use. They could even end up closing altogether.Gillian McKay, Unitersquos regional representative for East Lothian, said public toilets were a ldquobasic need for many.She said: ldquoHaving safe public toilets are essential for many people, including our elderly and those with medical conditions who need to plan a journey around access to a toilet.ldquoBus drivers and lorry drivers also need to be able to find the facilities.ldquoWe understand money needs to be saved but this is a soft target. Our toilets in East Lothian have won awards and the permanent attendants, many of whom are among the lowest paid workers, are dedicated to their role.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIn the challenging financial climate our priority is to seek new ways of maintaining services that meet the needs of residents and visitors while operating within our agreed budget.ldquoMobile toilet attendants already work across the majority of public toilet sites in the county and this is an area that we are exploring.ldquoOur employees are pivotal and as such a service review is being conducted which will include consultation with the unions and staff.The petition is at ipetitions petition save-east-lothian-public-toilets

title: details-of-tom-kitchins-east-lothian-pub-revealed
story: The transformation of the former Golf Inn in Gullane into The Bonnie Badger is well under way, with plans to open in December.Details of the new pub have now been revealed.Michelin star chef Kitchinrsquos we Michaela and dad Ron appeared before East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board to register the change of name for the venue, as well as asking for changes to previous licences.They revealed plans for  bedrooms ndash five of them in a cottage in the gardens of the pub ndash as well as a private dining room which would seat  and double as a conference or meeting room a main dining area outdoor eating area and a herb garden.They also applied for permission to provide off-sales from the pub so that people who buy a bottle of wine are able to take it homethere is some left when they leave.Their representative Caroline Loudon told the board that the Kitchin family had been ldquokeen to come to East Lothian for some time and were expecting a large number of guests who would be using the surrounding golf courses.Applying as well to be allowed to serve breakfast outside from am, she said: ldquoThere will be quite a lot of Americans coming and we would like to be able to offer teas and coffees in the morning, bearing in mind people will have early tee-times.The application to the board said: ldquoThe premises offer a range of other activities including: private dining experiences tastings education tours and learning experiences promotional and media activities fine dining experiences television and filming.It also listed corporate events, private hire, community and charity events, and auctions as possible activities.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, questioned the inclusion of plans for outdoor sports to be held at the pub in the application.However, Mrs Loudon said it was a ldquocatch-all to cover any events, citing an experience in Edinburgh where a premises held a foam party.She said: ldquoLicensing officers came in and said it was not an activity that was on the licence but everyone was foaming by that point.The board approved the iations to the licence, wishing the Kitchins well in their new venture.Councillor Jane Henderson, another ward member, said: ldquoI welcome this development and look forward to the end result. Thank you for making the investment.

title: bridge-in-north-berwick-labelled-an-accident-waiting-to-happen
story: Cash set aside by Cala Homes and currently with East Lothian Council could be used to install lights on the bridge at Ware Road.The bridge is used by motorists and pedestrians ndash and is a key route to school for children going to and from the high school and primary school ndash but its narrowness does not allow for a raised pavement.Residents attended a North Berwick Community Councilmeeting last week to share their ldquonear-miss experiences.Ian Watson, a long-serving community councillor, put forward traffic lights as a possible solution.He told the meeting: ldquoI propose that traffic lights like the ones [at the bridge] in Pencaitland are the best way forward.Mr Watson was referring to the lights that are in place at the narrow bridge on the A in Pencaitland.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, told the meeting: ldquoThere is money waiting to be spent from Cala [from a housing development in the town] and I think that you have just discussed what you need to do to spend it.Claire Mackenzie, interim chairwoman of the community council, said the group would write to East Lothian Council to find out how much has been ring-fenced.Mrs Mackenzie described the bridge, the only route over the townrsquos railway line, as a ldquodisaster.She said: ldquoI know people who are so worried about there being an accident there that they just avoid the bridge altogether.Members also discussed a proposal from NBCC member Gordon Moodie for a second bridge to be built across the railway line.On that suggestion, Mr Watson added: ldquoThat is something that we can dothere is [a lot of] money but it is an expensive solution.NBCC wants to engage with the community, including Law Primary School and North Berwick High School, about what they feel is the best solution.

title: princess-eugenie-and-jack-brooksbank-release-official-wedding-photographs
story: One intimate black and white image shows the couple having a kiss inside the Scottish State Coach as they ed to Windsor Castle after the carriage procession.The newlyweds are said to be ldquodelighted to share the four photographs, which were taken by British fashion and portrait photographer Alex Bramall.A group photograph taken in the White Drawing Room at Windsor shows both the bride and groomrsquos families.Eugeniersquos mother ndash Sarah, Duchess of York ndash is standing next to a seated Duke of Edinburgh, with the Duke of York to her other side, and all three are smiling for the camera.The Queenrsquos husband is thought to have a frosty relationship with ldquoFergie, who orced Andrew in .On Friday, a grinning Fergie gave a big sigh of relief as she took her seat in the chapel for the wedding ceremony, and spent a great deal of time waving at guests in the pews opposite.But she remained composed and kept her head slightly lowered when her former father-in-law passed her to take his seat in the row behind.It was believed to be the first time they had been pictured together in  years after she was cast out from the royals amid her ldquotoe sucking scandal in the s.An image of the bridal party shows Theodora, daughter of pop star Robbie Williams and we Ayda Field, standing right next to Mr Brooksbank, who rests his hand on her shoulder.Future king Prince George is looking at the camera with a beaming smile next to sister Princess Charlotte, who is dangling her legs with her feet crossed.In the fourth photograph, the newlyweds are pictured at the York family home, Royal Lodge in Windsor Great Park, ahead of the private evening dinner.Wearing a Zac Posen gown, Eugenie appears to be looking lovingly at her new husband, who is smiling at the camera and holding her hand.Buckingham Palace said Posen was inspired by the beauty of Windsor and the surrounding countryside, adding that the colour of the dress reflected the blush of an English rose.He also took inspiration for the design from the White Rose of York.The pin-tucked plisse is cut on the bias and mixed with signature drapes, and the White Rose of York is subtlety embroidered on both the shoulder and back which hold together the cape.The silk for the gown came from Biddle Sawyer Silk, the palace said.Eugenie set off her evening look with diamond and emerald drop earrings which were a wedding gt from the groom, and a hair slide belonging to the Queen.Photographer Bramall said it was ldquoan honour and a privilege to be invited to photograph the couple.

title: abe-renews-pledge-to-change-japans-charter-to-boost-troops
story: Speaking before a field of about , troops, Mr Abe said that a revision is needed to give his troops sense of pride.ldquoYou have gained public trust with your own hands, Mr Abe told the troops in his address.ldquoNow itrsquos time to fulfil our responsibility as politicians to accommodate an environment where all Self-Defensc Force can accomplish their duties with sense of pride.About  tanks and other military vehicles and  warplanes were exhibited at the event.Re-elected as head of his ruling party last month and with up to three more years as Japanrsquos leader, Mr Abe is determined to pursue his long-sought charter amendment.Many Japanese conservatives see Japanrsquos US-drafted constitution as a humiliation imposed after their World War II defeat.When the Self-Defence Force was established in , public opinion was initially ided over its role, but today the force has gained support for its largely non-combat contribution in international peace keeping efforts and disaster relief.Mr Abe wants to add a clause to Article  of the constitution, which bans the use of force in settling international disputes. He wants to explicitly permit the existence of Japanrsquos military.Opponents say such a revision is not necessary because the defence force is widely recognised in and outside the country as Japanrsquos military and its constitutionality is no longer an issue.Mr Abersquos ruling Liberal Democratic Party has continuously expanded the forcersquos international role by loosening interpretations of Article .In , his government passed a defence law allowing Japanese troops to defend US and other allies in case of foreign attack, a fundamental change from its self-defence only policy.Two-thirds approval is needed in both houses to propose a revision, which would then be subject to a national referendum.

title: harry-and-meghan-to-embark-on-first-royal-tour-as-couple
story: The royal couple will visit Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand between October  and .Starting on Tuesday, Harry and Meghan will take part in  engagements over their -day trip to the Pacic region.The tour coincides with the Invictus Games in Sydney, which run from October -.The sporting event ndash founded by Prince Harry in  ndash gives sick and injured service personnel and veterans the opportunity to compete in sports such as wheelchair basketball and sitting volleyball.After landing in Sydney, the duke and duchess will travel to Dubbo and Melbourne, before spending three days in Sydney from October - to mark the launch of the games. They willfor the closing ceremony.However,sport is not the sole focus of the trip. While in Australia, Harry and Meghan will also visit organisations including schools and a rural Flying Doctor service, greet members of the public at the Sydney Opera House, and meet young leaders and community members at Government House.After Australia, the couple will fly to Fiji, where they will be greeted with an arrival ceremony similar to one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in .In Fiji, Prince Harry will pay tribute to Fijian war veterans and the couple will attend a state dinner, before flying to Tonga.The tour will conclude with a four-day trip to New Zealand, where they will be greeted by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern.The duke and duchess will learn about environmental challenges while in Wellington, visit a charity which supports children with parents in prison, andmeet members of the public in Auckland and Rotura.Harry and Meghan willto London from Auckland on November .Kensington Palace said in a statement: ldquoThere is a long history of friendship between the Royal Family and Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand, and their links with the UK are extensive.ldquoThe duke and duchess are very much looking forward to experiencing the unique cultures and customs of those four Commonwealth countries and have asked that this tour allow them opportunities to meet as many Australians, Fijians, Tongans, and New Zealanders as possible.

title: pressure-mounts-on-theresa-may-as-brexit-summit-looms
story: As negotiations continue in Brussels ahead of a summit starting on Wednesday, the Prime Minister faces a political battle over a plan which could keep the UK in a customs union to avoid a hard border with Ireland.Former Brexit secretary David Davis said the plan was ldquocompletely unacceptable and urged Cabinet ministers to ldquoexert their collective authority.Meanwhile Democratic Unionist Party leader Arlene Foster is reported to have said that a no-deal Brexit was now the most likely outcome after talks with senior figures including Michel Barnier in Brussels.Her party is opposed to any customs arrangement which would result in Northern Ireland being ldquoannexed or impose extra checks on goods travelling to or from Great Britain.With continued speculation that Leave-supporting Cabinet ministers could resignMrs May presses ahead with the plan, David Davis said: ldquoThis is one of the most fundamental decisions that government has taken in modern times.Writing in the Sunday Times he said: ldquoIt is time for the Cabinet to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.The issue of the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland is one of the last remaining obstacles to achieving a orce deal with Brussels, with wrangling continuing over the nature of a ldquobackstop to keep the frontier opena wider UK-EU trade arrangement cannot resolve it.The European Unionrsquos version, which would see just Northern Ireland remain aligned with Brusselsrsquo rules, has been called unacceptable by Mrs May and is loathed by the DUP.Mrs Mayrsquos counter-proposal is for aldquotemporary customs arrangement for the whole UK, but Tory Brexiteers are suspicious this could turn into a permanent situation, restricting the freedom to strike trade deals around the world.The Sunday Times said at least nine ministers want Mrs May to change course when the Cabinet meets on Tuesday.Speculation about possible resignations has centred on Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey, but the newspaper also indicated that Scottish Secretary David Mundell and Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson could quit because special arrangements for Northern Ireland could fuel the case for Scottish independence.Mrs Mayrsquos own position also appeared in jeopardy, with as many as  letters demanding a vote of no confidence reportedly submitted to the Conservative  Committee ndash just four short of the number required to trigger a ballot.The Northern Irish situation is politically problematic for Mrs May because her minority administration depends on the votes of the  DUP MPs.A leaked email reported in the Observer indicated Mrs Foster was ready to block a Brexit deal.According to a private email exchange between senior UK officials, seen by the newspaper, Mrs Foster gave her views during a dinner with the leader of Conservative MEPs, Ashley Fox.The leaked email said Mrs Foster described the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator Mr Barnier as ldquodficult and hostile and indicated ldquothe DUP were ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one.Writing in the Belfaston Saturday, Mrs Foster said she appreciated the risks of a no-deal Brexit but ldquothe dangers of a bad deal are worse.She added: ldquoThe DUPrsquos actions this week are not as some have suggested about lsquoflexing musclersquo.ldquoThis is no game.ldquoAnyone engaging in this in a light-hearted way foolishly fails to grasp the gravity of the decisions we will make in the coming weeks.A further demonstration of Tory resistance to Mrs Mayrsquos plans came from MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan, who wrote in the Sundaythat ldquothe idea of remaining in the customs union ndash even itis called a lsquotemporary customs arrangementrsquo ndash after the end of the transition period, in to the s, means simply delaying Brexit and causing the . million people who voted for it to lose faith in our democracy.Jacob Rees-Mogg, chairman of the European Research Group of pro-Brexit MPs, warned that when it came to the backstop proposal ldquotemporary means eternal.In a letter to Chancellor Philip Hammond,  Tory MPs challenged him to release the full details of the cross-Whitehall Brexit analysis which forecast GDP growth would be . percentage points lower over  yearsthere was a ldquono-deal exit on World Trade Organisation rules.Former minister Steve Baker said:ldquoAfter several rounds of Project Fear, the reputation of government economic analysis is rock bottom. Itrsquos therefore time to reveal Governmentrsquos full working out for close scrutiny in the public interest.

title: hopes-of-new-blackadder-series-dashed
story: The show starring Rowan Atkinson as the anti-hero Edmund Blackadder and Sir Tony Robinson as his hapless servant Baldrick was cult viewing in the s.Also featuring were Hugh Laurie, Tim McInnerny, Stephen Fry and the late Rik Mayall with Ben Elton co-writing many of the episodes.The four series were each set in a dferent period of English history, covering the Middle Ages, Elizabethan England, the Georgian era and the First World War.Over the years there have been many people who wanted to see another series made with Blackadder set in modern times.Only last month, Sir Tony said he thought a fth series could be made, despite the original cast having very busy schedules.And last year Atkinson spoke of how  years ago there was an idea for a series set during the Russian Revolution, called Redadder, but plans went ldquonowhere.But Curtis, who went on to write blockbuster films Four Weddings And A Funeral, Love Actually, Notting Hill and Bridget Jonesrsquos Diary, scotched chances of a Blackadder revival.ldquoBlackadder is a very, very complicated group of people and soyou are fond enough of the series to wish that the people involved in it should live to a ripe old age then I think it is best that we donrsquot work together, thatrsquos the answer, Curtis said.The screenwriter was speaking during an event at the Cheltenham Literature Festival, in which he was interviewed by his daughter Scarlett, who revealed her mother, Emma Freud, has never watched an episode of Blackadder.Curtis explained how he and Atkinson, who himself has gone on to have global success with Mr Bean and Johnny English, dreamt up Blackadder.ldquoBlackadder was in a funny way written out of fear, Curtis said.ldquoSomeone called John Cleese had written a show called Fawlty Towers and when Rowan and I tried to write a modern situation comedy we just knew it was rubbish in comparison to that.ldquoSo we decided to write about history and it really came from two sources, one of which was a series of books called the Ladybird Book of History and the other was the plays of Shakespeare because they were also stupid and people also wore stupid costumes.Curtis added: ldquoI am sorry about the bad episodes they were all written by a guy called Ben Elton.He also gave some tips about his techniques for writing, saying that many wannabe writers give up too early.ldquoThe dference between me and a writer who doesnrsquot go on writing is that I write % good a day and I think that has been a fantastic day and many people give up writing because they write for a day and they have got % of rubbish, he said.ldquoI did once work out I had written , pages to reach Notting Hill which was a -page script.ldquoI think keeping faith and noticing whatrsquos good and I think the edits of movies are unbelievably rigorous and necessary and a few of my films have been not what I dreamed but they were finished.ldquoThe most interesting was Bridget which didnrsquot work at all until we moved the penultimate scene, which was her in absolute despair in her bedroom dressed in red pyjamas drinking and crying, to the title sequence of the movie, which meant you actually felt for Bridget right from the start, which in our original cut you just didnrsquot.ldquoThere are miraculous things that can happen in the edit.ldquoLove Actually is a bad example because it didnrsquot work at all when we finished it and the one where the finished product was at least like the script I wrote and in fact we had to delay the moviersquos release by three months to just start again.

title: sky-sports-reporter-blasts-hoops-fans-accusing-her-of-gers-bias-and-reveals-what-side-she-really-backs
story: Trolls accused Hayley McQueen of backing Rangers after a group of Hoops fans were unhappy with Skys Coverage of a recent match.Why you think Irsquom a Rangers fan, god knows, itrsquos obviously what you want to believe. I was born in Manchester  am a United fan, my hometown team Middlesbrough is also close to my heart."I was born in Manchester  am a United fan, my hometown team Middlesbrough is also close to my heart."

title: is-this-the-worlds-unhealthiest-pizza-glasgow-takeaway-launches-deep-fried-mars-bar-calzone
story: Described as a lsquoGlaswegian twistrsquo on the Italian food it is served with grated almonds on top of the pizza dough, caramel sauce and a scoop of chocolate ice cream.It is packed with Mars Bar chunks then cooked in batter and dubbed by locals as the Mars-gherita Pizza.With an estimated , calories packed into the snack, sold at Romans Pizzeria in Merchant City, Glaswegians have been flocking to try it.The takeaway is inspired by the notorious deep-fried Mars Bar treat invented in  at a Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, chippy - Haven Chip Bar .Romanrsquos general manager, Fraser Walker, said the idea behind the deep fried Mars Bar calzone came from a simple conversation with the head chef.The -year-old, from Kelvindale, said: "Well the shop has been open here for about five and a half months and we wanted to bring out something dferent."This is because we are known for our Roman-style pizza, and after speaking to the chef about dferent ideas we came up with that."Weve seen restaurants adding Nutella in a calzone so we just thought the deep fried mars bar is a Scottish thing. So why not put it in a calzone "Its definitely not a dessert for someone who is on a diet."I would say people should share it because its very sweet unless you have a sweet tooth or are really hungry."Costing pound., the calzone has been a hit with punters, with one person even asking a relative to send a pizza to Germany.Head chef, Dawid Radzinski, said: "Ive been a chef for  years and what weve done is completely original."When I first made it, we all tried it together and we all loved it. The dessert has been here since Monday and people think its really tasty."I think this was a great idea"INGREDIENTS:" pizza dough   caloriesTwo deep fried mars bars  , caloriesCaramel sauce g   caloriesOne tablespoonof sugar   caloriesA handful of almonds   caloriesOne scoop of chocolate ice cream   caloriesTotal  , calories

title: theresa-may-insists-she-would-never-agree-to-brexit-deal-that-trapped-uk-into-permanent-backstop
story: Downing Street made the declaration after it was suggested that several Cabinet ministers, following a briefing with the Prime Minister, were alarmed by the prospect of a proposal to keep all of the UK in the EU customs union until a trade deal was signed, which they fear would in fact go beyond the end of the transition period and in effect become a permanent position.But a No  spokeswoman said: "The Prime Minister would never agree to a deal which would trap the UK in a backstop permanently."She explained that Mrs May stood by the terms of her June proposal for a backstop arrangement for the Irish border, to take effect onlya broader trade assessment had not been finalised.The June document proposed that the whole of the UK would remain within a customs union until a deal on the future economic relationship was in place but made clear that Britain expected this would happen by the end of December .The spokeswoman added: "Our position is that this future economic relationship needs to be in place by the end of December  at the latest."On Thursday, David Mundell stressed how the backstop plan was only a fall-back guarantee should a trade deal not be completed by the end of the transition period and that the hope was it would never have to be implemented.But he made clear thatit were enacted, it had to be time-limited a proposal which Brussels has rebuffed, insisting any backstop has to be a permanent arrangement.Mr Mundell said: ldquoWhat is important is to recognise what we are talking about is a backstop provision. We are looking to have the future trade agreement and relationship set out almost simultaneouslyhellipWithin days of the withdrawal agreement, we will hopefully be setting out the terms of our future relationship and we want those to come into play on January   so we donrsquot want the backstop ever to be in place.He went on: ldquoThe backstop was there on the basisyou werenrsquot to get the other agreement implemented and, therefore, itrsquos still the case all the focus has to be on the initial agreement being implemented.ldquoIt is fair,there is to be a backstop, to set a time-limit on that backstop so that it couldnrsquot possibly exist either when the principal agreement came into full force or was indefinite so as to allow a situation, which wasnrsquot intended to be the negotiated arrangement for the UK and for Northern Irelandrsquos relationship with the EU to become a permanent fixture, said the Secretary of State.Mr Mundell also insisted reports that the PM was willing to see Northern Ireland remain in the European single market as the rest of the UK left it were untrue. ldquoThere is no plan for Northern Ireland to be in the single market, he declared.The Scottish Secretary stressed how he and Ruth Davidson, the Scottish Conservative leader, had made clear to Mrs May there fundamental opposition to any Brexit carve-out for Northern Ireland as it would undermine the integrity of the United Kingdom. Mr Mundell signalled thatthat were ever part of any proposed deal it would be a resignation matter for him.Meanwhile after Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionists threatened to vote down the Autumn Budgetany Brexit deal politically separated the region off from mainland Britain, Damian Green, the former Cabinet Office Minister, stressed how Mrs May was "a very Unionist Prime Minister".He claimed the PM and the DUP, whose  MPs prop up the Tory Government, were "as one" in their desire to see Northern Ireland treated like the rest of the UK.Mr Green told BBC Radio s Today: "She is a very Unionist PM, we are the Conservative and Unionist Party."She and the DUP are as one in wanting to make sure than Northern Ireland isnt in some way treated dferently from the rest of the United Kingdom in trade or customs terms and that is an absolutely key point in these negotiations, as the DUP have pointed out."

title: independent-scotland-would-be-welcomed-back-into-eu-labour-grandee-says
story: David Martin ndash the second longest-serving MEP in Europe ndash said sympathy was growing in Brussels over Scotland being ldquoforced out of the EU against its will.He said negotiations would be ldquoquick given Scotland would meet nearly all of the conditions for membership, and argued a ldquobespoke deal would enable it to stay out of the eurozone.Scottish Labour dismissed his remarks as "hypothetical statements which do not reflect Scottish Labour policy in any way, shape, or form.Mr Martin said Scotlandrsquos future membership of the EU was not ldquohigh on peoplersquos agenda in Brussels, but added: ldquoIt is talked about, and there are people who would not previously have been sympathetic to the idea of an independent Scotland ndash colleagues of mine, Irsquom talking non-British colleagues ndash who now talk about it openly and say to me, lsquoAre you going to be an independent country, are you likely to join as a separate country rsquoldquoI think there is a dference between now and the time of the Scottish referendum where we were seen to be leaving a member state and we were pulling ourselves out of the EU in some peoples eyes.ldquoThis time around weare being forced out of the EU, which is how it is perceived here.ldquoThey know that Scotland voted to Remain and I think they would be very sympatheticScotland came back and said, lsquoScotland became independent and it wants to join the EUrsquo. It would be welcome.He said a bespoke deal on joining the euro would be offered ldquobecause other countries have it and it wouldnrsquot be a problem that you didnrsquot sign up to the euro.A major SNP report earlier this year suggested keeping the pound for at least ten years after independence, before moving towards a new currency.It insisted Scotland would not be obliged to join the euroit became a member of the EU, pointing to the example of other countries such as Sweden and Denmark.Mr Martin, a Labour MEP since , said plans to keep the pound ndash as outlined in the SNPs Growth Commission report ndash would probably be accepted by Brussels.He said Scotland would not have to queue behind others seeking to gain membership ndash such as Montenegro, Serbia and Albania ndash but would ldquohave to nevertheless go through the process of the negotiation and fulfill all the conditions.Mr Martin previously refused to rule out backing independence in order to secure links with Europe.A Scottish Labour spokesman insisted his remarks did not reflect party policy.He added: ldquoIf Brexit has made one thing clear, it is that there are severe challenges in leaving a political and economic union. All of the challenges we see with leaving the EU would be repeated on a much larger scale with leaving the UK.An SNP spokeswoman said: ldquoBrexit means there is now a much more positive view of an independent Scotland among our European friends and neighbours.ldquoAnd the Toriesrsquo shambolic handling of Brexit has killed off the credibility of any future lsquoProject Fearrsquo campaign against independence.ldquoScotland has been part of the EU for  years, meaning we already meet the rules, so we would be very well prepared to join as an independent nation."

title: first-scottish-female-film-director-to-be-honoured-at-national-film-theatre
story: But now the le and career of Scotlandrsquos first female film director is being celebrated with a major retrospective of her work, being organised by the British Film Institute to mark the centenary of her birth next month.Orcadian Margaret Tait was a distinguished poet, writer and filmmaker, who made history as the first female Scots director of a feature- film.ldquoTaitrsquos unique mix of image, sound, rhythm and poetry reminds us of what cinema is and can be, explained a British Film Institute spokesperson.Described by the acclaimed Scots playwright Ali smith as ldquoa unique and underrated filmmaker, Tait was born in Kirkwall on  November  and later moved to Edinburgh to study medicine, serving with the Royal Army Medical Corps in India and the Far East during the Second World War.After the war she moved to Rome to study film at the prestigious Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia, and made her first short film, One Is One, in Italy in .In  she ed to Scotland, settling in Edinburgh and founding Ancona Films, eventually making over thirty short films ranging infrom three minutes to over an hour, most of which examined everyday le in the city.She also published several books of poetry.ldquoThe kind of cinema I care about is at the level of poetry, she explained. ldquoIn fact, it has been in a way my lersquos work making film poems.Among her best known works are Hugh MacDiarmid: A Portrait, a documentary about Scotlandrsquos most famous th century poet, and Where I Am Is Here, both shot in Edinburgh in .Of the latter, Tait said: ldquoStarting with a six-line script which just noted down a kind of event to occur, and recur, my aim was to construct a film with its own logic, its own correspondences within itself, its own echoes and rhymes and comparisons, all through close exploration of the everyday, the commonplace, in the city, Edinburgh.Her work was noted for its impressionistic style and unique use of music. ldquoAlthough I donrsquot understand musical structure - I canrsquot really follow the structure of a piece of music when Irsquom listening to it - I think that film structure is more like musical structure than anything , she once said.But her films were perceived as having little commercial appeal and she struggled to attract the interest of film distributors.ldquoAs it turned out, of course, distributors then were not interested in independently produced short films. There was, in fact, not really a market at all, she admitted.Consequently, Tait had to finance almost all her films herself and, although she gained some favourable critical attention during her letime, her films were not widely seen by the public.In  she ed to her beloved Orkneys and worked as a locum to fund her short films, most of which focused on the relationship between Orcadians and the land and sea.Finally in , at the age of , she secured a budget to make her one and only feature- film, the first to ever be directed by a Scottish female director.Blue Black Permanent, which she had originally conceived in the s, starred Celia Imrie and explored the lives of three generations of women from an Orcadian family.She continued working almost until her death at the age of  in , her last project being the short film Garden Pieces.ldquoI actually picked up a camera in the last few days to work on something in the old style, meaning mm, self-produced and self everything , she said shortly before her death.Although regarded as something of a forgotten figure in Scotland, in recent years her role as a pioneer of Scottish filmmaking has begun to be more widely recognised, and in  the Glasgow Film Festival founded the Margaret Tait Award ldquoto support experimental and innovative artists working with film and the moving image in Scotland.Rhythm and Poetry - The Films of Margaret Tait - runs at selected independent cinemas around the country from  October until  November.The highlight of the season will be a special screening of a digitally remastered print of Blue Black Permanent at the National Film Theatre in London and the Glasgow Film Theatre on  November, to mark the centenary of her birth.

title: young-singer-named-gaelic-ambassador-of-the-year
story: TheGaelic cultural festival started on Friday with aspecial celebration honouring Scotlandrsquos Year of Young Peopleat a ceremony in the Queens Hall in Dunoon, Argyll and Bute.The audience heard from the Royal National Modrsquos president Allan Campbell before traditional groups SIAN and Beinn Lee took to the stage for an evening of music.The groups were invited to perform at the ceremony as part of the Year of Young People celebrations, with all members in their twenties.Earlier in the day, the ldquoprestigious Gaelic ambassador of the year award was presented to -year-old Eilidh Cormack, from Portree on Skye.The award, presented by MSP Michael Russell, celebrated how much she has accomplished within the Gaelic community at such a young age, and what lies ahead for her in the future.She said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted to have been awarded with the Gaelic ambassador of the year at the Royal National Mod this year and I certainly wasnrsquot expecting it, especially being so young.ldquoItrsquos going to encourage me to not only look back and appreciate what Irsquove been doing and what the Mod have recognised, but also encourage me to keep doing it for years to come.In his speech, Mr Campbell paid tribute to the late John Macleod, who was president of theMod for  years and announced that An Comunn Gaidhealach, organisers of the Mod,will establish an annual lecture in his memory.The first annual John Macleod Memorial Lecture will take place in January  at the University of Edinburgh, where Mr Macleod studied Law.The lectures will be hosted by the Department of Celtic and Scottish Studies and will always be delivered by speakers under  years of age, in a nod to Mr Macleodrsquos enthusiasm and encouragement of young people in the Gaelic community.John Morrison, chief executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, said: ldquoWe are delighted to kickstart this yearrsquos Royal National Mod and are excited to showcase Scotlandrsquos best Gaelic talent once more.ldquoThe announcement honouring the late John Macleod is something we have been working to bring to fruition for some time, and we cannot think of a more fitting tribute for a man who offered so much to the Gaelic community in his time.ldquoThis year we are celebrating young people in our community, and we aimed to reflect this with our opening ceremony performers and co-host, as well as the deserving Gaelic ambassador of the year award recipient. Eilidh Cormack is an exceptional talent.ldquoWe are certain she has a bright future and that her role as Gaelic ambassador of the year will inspire others to follow in Eilidhrsquos footsteps.The eight-day festival will feature more than  competitions and events in Highland dancing, sport, literature, drama, Gaelic music and song, with Gaelic speakers of all levels competing.As well as the competitions, this yearrsquos Fringe showcases the best of Gaelic arts and sport with events for all ages, from ceilidhs to drama and several musical performances.

title: pressure-mounts-on-theresa-may-as-brexit-summit-looms
story: As negotiations continue in Brussels ahead of a summit starting on Wednesday, the Prime Minister faces a political battle over a plan which could keep the UK in a customs union to avoid a hard border with Ireland.Former Brexit secretary David Davis said the plan was ldquocompletely unacceptable and urged Cabinet ministers to ldquoexert their collective authority.Meanwhile Democratic Unionist Party leader Arlene Foster is reported to have said that a no-deal Brexit was now the most likely outcome after talks with senior figures including Michel Barnier in Brussels.Her party is opposed to any customs arrangement which would result in Northern Ireland being ldquoannexed or impose extra checks on goods travelling to or from Great Britain.With continued speculation that Leave-supporting Cabinet ministers could resignMrs May presses ahead with the plan, David Davis said: ldquoThis is one of the most fundamental decisions that government has taken in modern times.Writing in the Sunday Times he said: ldquoIt is time for the Cabinet to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.The issue of the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland is one of the last remaining obstacles to achieving a orce deal with Brussels, with wrangling continuing over the nature of a ldquobackstop to keep the frontier opena wider UK-EU trade arrangement cannot resolve it.The European Unionrsquos version, which would see just Northern Ireland remain aligned with Brusselsrsquo rules, has been called unacceptable by Mrs May and is loathed by the DUP.The Sunday Times said at least nine ministers want Mrs May to change course when the Cabinet meets on Tuesday.Speculation about possible resignations has centred on Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey, but the newspaper also indicated that Scottish Secretary David Mundell and Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson could quit because special arrangements for Northern Ireland could fuel the case for Scottish independence.Mrs Mayrsquos own position also appeared in jeopardy, with as many as  letters demanding a vote of no confidence reportedly submitted to the Conservative  Committee ndash just four short of the number required to trigger a ballot.The Northern Irish situation is politically problematic for Mrs May because her minority administration depends on the votes of the  DUP MPs.A leaked email reported in the Observer indicated Mrs Foster was ready to block a Brexit deal.According to a private email exchange between senior UK officials, seen by the newspaper, Mrs Foster gave her views during a dinner with the leader of Conservative MEPs, Ashley Fox.The leaked email said Mrs Foster described the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator Mr Barnier as ldquodficult and hostile and indicated ldquothe DUP were ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one.Writing in the Belfaston Saturday, Mrs Foster said she appreciated the risks of a no-deal Brexit but ldquothe dangers of a bad deal are worse.She added: ldquoThe DUPrsquos actions this week are not as some have suggested about lsquoflexing musclersquo.ldquoThis is no game.ldquoAnyone engaging in this in a light-hearted way foolishly fails to grasp the gravity of the decisions we will make in the coming weeks.

title: princess-eugenie-and-jack-brooksbank-release-official-wedding-photographs
story: One intimate black and white image shows the couple having a kiss inside the Scottish State Coach as they ed to Windsor Castle after the carriage procession.The newlyweds are said to be sucking scandal in the s.An image of the bridal party shows Theodora, daughter of pop star Robbie Williams and we Ayda Field, standing right next to Mr Brooksbank, who rests his hand on her of York is subtlety embroidered on both the shoulder and back which hold together the cape.The silk for the gown came from Biddle Sawyer Silk, the palace said.Eugenie set off her evening look with title: co-operative-party-backs-peoples-vote-on-brexit-deal
story: The Co-operative Party, which has  MPs who are jointly members of Labour, also backed continued membership of the single market.At the partyrsquos conference in Bristol, delegates also rejected the prospect of a no-deal Brexit and said the Article  period should be extendedan agreement has not been reached by March .The explicit call for a second referendum goes further than Labourrsquos position, which is only to keep the option of a public vote on the tablea Brexit deal is rejected by Parliament and there is not a general election.The @CoopParty Conference confirms strong supp for a public Vote on whether to accept the Brexit deal  that that deal should include m ship of and access to the Single Mkt. If no agreement can b reached by  March next yr an extension to the Article  deadline shd b soughtmdash Gareth ThomasOctober , Co-operative Party chairman and MP Gareth Thomassaid: ldquoMembers of the Co-operative Party have today voted to put the British people back at the heart of the Brexit process, by backing a peoplersquos vote on the final Brexit deal.Our party has also been clear that no-deal is not an option.ldquoAs we work towards building a Britain where wealth and power are shared, it is vital that Brexit does not lead Britain down a path of greater inequality, insecurity and isolation.ldquoInstead we need a Britain with co-operative values of democracy, equality and solidarity at its heart. This is what is at stake.ldquoWe call on the Prime Minister to listen to the growing number of people and organisations who are saying the people should be in the driving seat.
